The 1987 Education Act aimed at turning the 1974’s Dozbo committee measures into reality: a national literacy campaign was launched, pre-tertiary education was reduced from 17 to 12 years and vocational education appeared in Junior High School. Education was made compulsory from 6 to 14. The reform succeeded in imposing a new education structure, as well as to increase the enrollment and the number of infrastructure.{{cite web | url=http://ceid.educ.cam.ac.uk/publications/WP16.pdf | title=The financing and outcomes of Education in Ghana | publisher=University of Cambridge | accessdate=13 June 2014 |author1=Nii Moi Thompson |author2=Leslie Casely-Hayford | page=26}} Yet the promise of universal access to basic education was not fulfilled.{{cite web | url=http://www.norrag.org/en/publications/norrag-news/online-version/critical-perspectives-on-education-and-skills-in-eastern-africa-on-basic-and-post-basic-levels/detail/participation-of-private-schools-in-basic-education-provision-in-ghana.html | title=Critical Perspectives on Education and skills in eastern Africa on basic and post-basic Levels | publisher=NORRAG | date=2003 | accessdate=13 June 2014 | author=Joshua J.K. Baku, ERNWACA}} Vocational programs were also considered as a failure. The return to constitutional rule in 1992, though still under Rawlings government, gave a new impulse by reclaiming the duty of the state to provide a free and compulsory basic education for all.{{cite web | url=http://www.ibe.unesco.org/fileadmin/user_upload/Publications/WDE/2010/pdf-versions/Ghana.pdf | title=World Data on Education | publisher=UNESCO-IBE | date=September 2010 | accessdate=13 June 2014 | page=3}} The local government Act of 1993 initiated the decentralization in education administration, by transferring power to district assemblies. The Free, Compulsory and Universal Basic Education(FCUBE) provided an action plan for the period 1996-2005, focusing on bridging the gender gap in primary-school, improving teaching materials and teacher’s living condition. It was later completed by significant acts, like the creation of the “Council for Technical and Vocational Education and Training” in order to promote vocational education(2006), or the founding of the national accreditation board (2007), introducing a national accreditation for all tertiary level institution. In 2007-2008, the two years in Kindergarten were added to the free and compulsory education (which is now going age 4 to 14). {|class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto;" |+Evolution of enrollment and infrastructures in compulsory education since 1968 |- !x !1968(public sector only){{cite web | url=http://wikieducator.org/images/4/4f/DEMAND_SUPPLY_present.pdf | title=Demand and supply of basic school teachers in Ghana | publisher=University College of Education of Winneba | date=2000 | accessdate=25 September 2014 | author=D. K. Mereku}}{{cite web | url=http://cepa.org.gh/researchpapers/BASIC%20EDUCATION%20IN%20GHANA%20IN%20THE%20POST1.pdf | title=Basic education in Ghana in the post-reform period | publisher=Centre for Policy Analysis, Accra | date=2000 | accessdate=25 September 2014 | author=Abena D. Oduro}} !1988 !2001{{cite web | url=http://www.moe.gov.gh/docs/Basic/2001-2002/Profile_National_2001_02.pdf | title=National Profile - 2001 / 2002 School Year Data | publisher=Ministry of Education, Ghana | accessdate=25 September 2014}} !2007{{cite web | url=http://www.moe.gov.gh/docs/Basic/2007-2008/Basic%20National%20Profile.pdf | title=National Profile - 2007 / 2008 School Year Data | publisher=Ministry of Education, Ghana | accessdate=25 September 2014}} !2012{{cite web | url=http://www.moe.gov.gh/docs/Basic/2012-2013/Basic%20National%20Profile.pdf | title=National Profile - 2012 / 2013 School Year Data | publisher=Ministry of Education, Ghana | accessdate=25 September 2014}} |- !Pupils |1,397,026||x||4,154,374||5,024,944||7,465,208 |- !Teachers |47,880||97,920||155,879||229,144||268,619 |- !Schools |x||x||32,501||46,610||56,919 |} ==Statistics== Ghana's spending on education has been around 25% of its annual budget in the past decade. The Ghanaian education system from Kindergarten up to an undergraduate degree level takes 20 years.[http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/education/ "Education in Ghana"] ghanaweb.com[http://www.nab.gov.gh/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=53&Itemid=182 "What to know about the National Accreditation Board (NAB)"]. NAB.gov.gh. Retrieved 27 April 2010. {{multiple image | footer = | header = | align = right | image1 = Ghana Ratio of Girls to Boys in Primary and Secondary Education.png | width1 = {{#expr: (195 * 750 / 536) round 0}} | alt1 = | caption1 = Ratio of females to males in education system. | image2 = Ghana Children Out Of School.png | width2 = {{#expr: (195 * 750 / 536) round 0}} | alt2 = | caption2 =
Females and males out of education system.
}} The ratio of females to males in the total education system was 96.38% in 2011.{{cite web|url=http://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SE.ENR.PRSC.FM.ZS |title=Ratio of girls to boys in primary and secondary education (%)|website= data.worldbank.org| publisher= |date= |accessdate=21 July 2013}} The adult literacy rate in Ghana was 71.5% in 2010, with males at 78.3% and females at 65.3%.[https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/fields/2103.html Field Listing: Literacy].cia.gov. Retrieved 24 June 2013. The youth female and male ages 15–24 years literacy rate in Ghana was 81% in 2010, with males at 82%,{{cite web|url=http://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SE.ADT.1524.LT.MA.ZS/countries|title=Literacy rate, youth male (% of males ages 15-24) |website=worldbank.org|publisher=''[[World Bank]]''|date=|accessdate=29 July 2013}} and females at 80%.{{cite web|url=http://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SE.ADT.1524.LT.FE.ZS|title=Literacy rate, youth female (% of females ages 15-24) |website=worldbank.org|publisher=''[[World Bank]]''|date=|accessdate=29 July 2013}} Since 2008, enrollment has continually increased at all level of education (pre-primary, primary, secondary and tertiary education).{{sfn|Ministry of Education|2013|loc=Table (p. 9), Table 6 (p. 30), Table 46 (p. 48)}} With 84% of its children in primary school, Ghana has a school enrollment "far ahead" of its sub-saharian neighbor's.{{cite web|url=http://www.unicef.org/wcaro/wcaro_GHA_MTSP2.pdf |title=UNICEF – Basic Education and Gender Equality |website= unicef.org|publisher= [[UNICEF|United Nations Children's Fund]] (UNICEF) |date= |accessdate=1 April 2012}} The number of infrastructures has increased consequently on the same period.{{sfn|Ministry of Education|2013|loc=Table 2 (p. 25), Table 4 (p. 27), Table 6 (p. 30), Table 26 (p. 55)}} Vocational Education (in "TVET institutes", not-including SHS vocational and technical programs) is the only exception, with an enrollment decrease of 1,3% and the disappearance of more than 50 institutions between the years 2011/12 and 2012/2013.{{sfn|Ministry of Education|2013|p=65}} This drop would be the result of the low prestige of Vocational Education and the lack of demand from industry.{{sfn|Ministry of Education|2013|p=66}} {|class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto;" |+Enrollment and [[Gross Enrollment Ratio|GER]] in pre-tertiary(2012/2013){{sfn|Ministry of Education|2013|loc=Table (p. 9), Table 6 (p. 30)}} |- !x !{{abbr|KG|Kindergarten}} !{{abbr|Prim|Primary School}} !{{abbr|JHS|Junior High School}} !{{abbr|SHS|Senior High School}} !{{abbr|TVET|Technical and vocational Education and Training institutes}} |- !Enrollment |1,604,505||4,105,913||1,452,585||842,587||61,496 |- |[[Gross Enrollment Ratio|GER]] in % |113.8||105.0||82.2||36.8||2.7 |} {|class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto;" |+Number of structures in pre-tertiary education (2012/2013){{sfn|Ministry of Education|2013|loc=Table 2 (p. 25), Table 4 (p. 27), Table 6 (p. 30), Table 26(p. 55)}} |- !x !{{abbr|KG|Kindergarten}} !{{abbr|Prim|Primary School}} !{{abbr|JHS|Junior High School}} !{{abbr|SHS|Senior High School}} !{{abbr|TVET|Technical and vocational Education and Training institutions}} |- !Public |13,305||14,112||8,818||535||107 |- !Private |5,972||5,742||3,618||293||74 |- !Total |19,277||19,854||12,436||828||181 |} Ministry of Education statistics showed 261,962 tertiary students during the 2011/2012 schoolyear:{{sfn|Ministry of Education|2013|loc=Table 46 (p. 78)}} 202,063 in the public sector and 59,899 in the private sector, attending 142 institutions.{{sfn|Ministry of Education|2013|loc=Table 46 (p. 78)}} In 2011, the primary school net enrolment rate was 84%, a figure described by [[UNICEF]] as "far ahead" of the [[Sub-Saharan Africa|Sub-Saharan]] average.{{cite web | url=http://www.unesco.org/new/fileadmin/MULTIMEDIA/HQ/ED/pdf/EDUCATION_IN_GHANA_A_FACT_SHEET.pdf | title=Fact sheet, Education in Ghana | publisher=UNICEF | date=October 2012 | accessdate=15 May 2014 | page=1, table comparing sub–sahara to Ghana}} In its 2013-14 report, the [[World Economic Forum]] ranked Ghana 46th out of 148 countries regarding the education system quality.{{cite web | url=http://www3.weforum.org/docs/WEF_GlobalCompetitivenessReport_2013-14.pdf | title=Global competitiveness report | publisher=World Economic Forum | date=2014 | accessdate=26 July 2014 | page=196}} ==Structure of formal education== ===Overview=== [[File:Ghana Education Structure.gif|thumb|right|550px|
[[Education]] structure of Ghana
]] The Ghanaian education system is divided in three parts: "Basic Education", secondary cycle and tertiary Education. "Basic Education" lasts 11 years(Age 4-15), is free and compulsory.{{cite web | url=http://www.ges.gov.gh/?q=content/basic-education-curriculum-1 | title=Basic Education curriculum | publisher=Ghana Education Service (GES) | accessdate=25 May 2014}} It is divided into Kindergarten(2 years), primary school(2 modules of 3 years) and Junior High school(3 years). The junior high school(JHS) ends on the Basic Education Certificate Examination ([[BECE]]). Once the BECE achieved, the pupil can pursue into secondary cycle.{{cite web | url=http://www.ghanawaec.org/EXAMS/BECE.aspx | title=BECE | accessdate=28 May 2014 | author=West African Examinations Council(corporate site: Ghana)}} Secondary cycle can be either general (assumed by Senior High School) or vocational(assumed by technical Senior High School, Technical and vocational Institutes and a massive private and informal offer). Senior High school lasts three years and ends on the West African Secondary School Certificate Examination ([[WASSCE]]). Other secondary institutions leads to various certifications and diplomas. Tertiary education is basically divided into university (academic education) and Polytechnics(vocational education). The WASSCE is needed to join a university bachelor's degree program.{{sfn|NUFFIC|2013|page=7}}A bachelor's degree lasts 4 years and can be followed by a 1 or 2 year Master. The student is then free to start a Phd, usually completed in 3 years.{{sfn|NUFFIC|2013|page=9}} Polytechnics are opened to vocational students, from SHS or from TVI.{{cite web | url=http://www.unevoc.unesco.org/worldtvetdatabase1.php?ct=GHA | title=Vocational Education in Ghana | publisher=UNESCO-UNEVOC | date=July 2012 | accessdate=23 May 2014}} A Polytechnic curriculum lasts 2 to 3 years. Ghana also possesses numerous colleges of education.{{sfn |Atuahene, Ansah|2013|p=2}} New tertiary education graduates have to serve one year within the National Service Scheme.{{cite web | url=http://dev.icicp.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/Ghana-Country-Profile-.pdf | title=Country profile: Ghana | publisher=International Association for National Youth Service | date=2012 | accessdate=28 July 2014}}{{cite web | url=http://196.201.43.251/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=78&Itemid=103 | title=Mandate of the NSS | publisher=National Service Scheme (NSS) | accessdate=28 July 2014}} The Ghanaian education system from Kindergarten up to an undergraduate degree level takes 20 years.{{cite web|url=http://www.tobeworldwide.org/index.php?option=com_docman&task=doc_view&gid=4 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110809071841/http://www.tobeworldwide.org/index.php?option=com_docman&task=doc_view&gid=4 |archivedate=2011-08-09 |title=A Brief History of the Ghanaian Educational System|website=TobeWorldwide.org}} The academic year usually goes from August to May inclusive.{{sfn|NUFFIC|2013|pages=4–5}} The school year lasts 40 weeks in Primary school and SHS, and 45 weeks in JHS.{{sfn|NUFFIC|2013|p=5}} ===Basic Education=== {{further|List of schools in Ghana}} Basic Education lasts 11 years. The curriculum is free and compulsory (Age 4-15) and is defined as "the minimum period of schooling needed to ensure that children acquire basic literacy, numeracy, and problem-solving skills as well as skills for creativity and healthy living". It is divided into Kindergarten, Primary school and Junior High School (JHS), which ends on the Basic Education Certificate Examination ([[BECE]]). '''Kindergarten''' lasts 2 years (Age 4-6). The program is divided into 6 core areas: Language and Literacy (Language Development), Creative Activities (Drawing and Writing), Mathematics (Number Work), Environmental Studies, Movement and Drama (Music and Dance), and Physical Development (Physical Education) '''Primary school''' lasts 6 years (Age 6-11). The courses taught at the primary or basic school level include English, Ghanaian languages and Ghanaian culture, ICT, mathematics, environmental studies, social studies, Mandarin and French as an [[Organisation Internationale de la Francophonie|OIF]] associated-member; integrated or general science, pre-[[Vocational education|vocational]] skills and pre-[[Technical education|technical]] skills, religious and moral education, and physical activities such as Ghanaian music and dance, and physical education. There is no certificate of completion at the end of primary school.{{sfn|NUFFIC|2013|pages=4–5}} '''Junior Secondary School''' lasts 3 years(Age 12-15).{{cite web | url=http://www.ges.gov.gh/?q=content/basic-education-curriculum | title=Basic curriculum Education: The Junior High Education | publisher=Ghana Education Service | accessdate=28 May 2014}} The Junior High School ends on the Basic Education Certificate([[BECE]]), which covers the following subjects:English Language, Ghanaian Language and Culture, Social Studies, Integrated Science, Mathematics, Basic, Design and Technology, Information and Communication Technology, French (optional), Religious and Moral Education. ===Secondary cycle=== {{Further|List of senior secondary schools in Ghana}} {{multiple image | align = right | header = | image1 = Pope John Senior High School and Minor Seminary students receive their WASSCE upon Graduation.jpg | alt1 = | width1 = 215 | caption1 = [[Senior High School]] [[Student]]s of the [[Pope John Senior High School and Minor Seminary]] receiving their [[WASSCE]] upon [[Graduation]] prior to entering [[University education|University Education]] for their [[Academic degree|Academic Degrees]] in Ghana. | image2 = Accra Aca 81st Anniversary Science Exhibition.JPG | alt2 = | width2 = 190 | caption2 = Ghana [[High school]] Students of the [[Accra Academy]]; Learning [[Science]] and undertaking Scientific tests in [[Laboratory|Science Laboratory]]. }} Students who pass the [[Basic Education Certificate Examination|BECE]] can proceed into secondary education, general or vocational. '''The secondary general education is assumed by the Senior High School(SHS)'''. The SHS [[curriculum]] is composed of core subjects, completed by elective subjects(chosen by the students). The core subjects are English language, mathematics, integrated science (including science, ICT and environmental studies) and social studies (economics, geography, history and government). The students then choose 3 or 4 elective subjects from 5 available programmes: agriculture programme, general programme (divided in 2 options: arts or science), business programme, [[Vocational education|vocational]] programme and [[Technical education|technical]] programme.{{cite web | url=http://www.ghanawaec.org/EXAMS/WASSCE.aspx | title=WASSCE - subjects for examination | date=2012 | accessdate=18 May 2014 | author=West African Examinations Council (WAEC)}} The Senior high school's curriculum lasts 3 years, as a result of numerous reforms: Originally a three-year curriculum, it was extended to 4 years in 2007.{{cite web | url=http://www.modernghana.com/news/475340/1/the-2007-educational-reform-and-its-callenges.html | title=The 2007 education Reform and its challenges | accessdate=28 May 2014 | author=Modern Ghana}} However, in early 2009 this reform returned SHS to a 3-year curriculum.{{cite web | url=http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/NewsArchive/artikel.php?ID=167932 | title=3-year SHS programme starts next year | date=2 September 2009 | accessdate=28 May 2014 | author=Ghanaweb}} The length of the SHS is still a disputed question.{{cite web | url=http://tv3network.com/Education/bring-back-4-year-shs-system-catholic-bishops.html | title= Bring back the 4 year SHS system | accessdate=18 May 2014 | author=TV3 Network}}{{cite web | url=http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/features/artikel.php?ID=275876 | title=The fate of Ghana's Education system | date=5 June 2013 | accessdate=18 May 2014 | author=Ghana Web}} The SHS ends on a final exam called the [[West African Senior School Certificate Examination]] (WASSCE), formerly called Senior Secondary School Certificate (SSSC) before 2007.{{sfn|NUFFIC|2013|page=11}} A SHS ranking is established every year by the Statistics, Research, Information, Management and Public Relations (SRIMPR) division of the ministry of Education, based on the WASSCE results.{{cite web | url=http://exposeghana.com/2014/03/2013-wassce-shs-rankings-full-list/ | title=2013 WASSCE SHS Rankings- Full List | date=March 2014 | accessdate=18 May 2014 | author=Expose Ghana}} '''Vocational and technical Education''' (also called “TVET”) take different forms. After obtaining the BECE, students who wish to pursue in vocational Education have two main possibilities: Following the vocational and technical programs as elective courses in a SHS, or joining a technical and vocational institute(TVI). SHS students follow the usual SHS 3 year curriculum. They can then – provided sufficient results at the WASSCE – join a university or polytechnic program.{{cite web | url=http://www.gesci.org/assets/files/COTVET%20report.pdf | title=From prejudice to prestige: Vocational education and training in Ghana | publisher=Council for Technical and Vocational Education and Training (COTVET) | date=2011 | accessdate=28 May 2014}} TVI students usually follow a 4-year curriculum, divided into two cycles of two years, leading to “awards from City & Guilds, the Royal Society of Arts or the West African Examinations Council". They can then pursue a polytechnic program. The state of vocational education sector remains however obscure in Ghana: 90% of the vocational education is still informal, taking the form of apprenticeship. The offer of formal vocational education within the private sector is also hard to define{{sfn|Ministry of Education|2013|page=65}} and the [[Ministry of Education]] recognizes its incapacity to give a clear overview of the public vocational education, many ministries having their own programs.{{sfn|Ministry of Education|2013|page=65}} International schools also exist in Ghana: the [[Takoradi International School]], Tema International School, [[Galaxy International School, Accra|Galaxy International School]], The Roman Ridge School, [[Ghana International School]], [[Lincoln Community School]], Faith Montessori School, American International School, Association International School, New Nation School, SOS Hermann Gmeiner International College and International Community School, which offer the [[International Baccalaureat]], [[Advanced Level General Certificate of Education]] and the [[International General Certificate of Secondary Education]] (IGCSE). ===Tertiary education=== {{Further|List of universities in Ghana}} {{multiple image | align = right | header = | width = 272 | image1 = University of Education, Winneba (UEW) North Campus.jpg | alt1 = | caption1 = Front view of the [[University of Education, Winneba]] (UEW) North [[Campus]] in Winneba. | image2 = College of Engineering, KNUST Auditorium.JPG | alt2 = | caption2 = Ghana [[University]] students at the [[Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology]] (KNUST) in Kumasi, February 2011. }} Tertiary education in Ghana has been notably growing during the last twenty years, both in terms of enrollment and infrastructures.{{sfn |Atuahene, Ansah|2013|p=2}} A substantial part of this development come from the private sector.{{sfn |Atuahene, Ansah|2013|p=2}}{{cite web | url=http://www.ibe.unesco.org/International/ICE47/English/Natreps/reports/ghana.pdf | title=The development of Education: National report of Ghana | publisher=IBE | date=2004 | accessdate=23 May 2014}}[http://www.nab.gov.gh/index.php?option=com_content&view=category&layout=blog&id=60&Itemid=185&limitstart=30 "Ghana private tertiary institutions offering degree program"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131002212350/http://www.nab.gov.gh/index.php?option=com_content&view=category&layout=blog&id=60&Itemid=185&limitstart=30 |date=2013-10-02 }} Retrieved 2 January 2011.{{cite web | url=http://www.nab.gov.gh/index.php?option=com_content&view=category&layout=blog&id=65&Itemid=193 | title=Private Colleges of Education | publisher=National Accreditation Board (NAB) | accessdate=23 May 2014}} Universities(6 public and 49 private institutions){{sfn |Atuahene, Ansah|2013|p=2}} offer an academic education, from bachelor to Phd. Students are admitted based on their performance at the W.A.S.S.C.E ([[West African Senior School Certificate Examination]]"): A maximum of 24 points is generally required in order to apply to a Bachelor degree program(see [[Education in Ghana#Grading System|Grading system in Ghana]]). A bachelor degree is usually completed after four years of majoring in a specific field of interest.{{sfn|NUFFIC|2013|pages=9–10}} Master degrees are of two sorts: A one year program, concluded with a final paper based on a literature study, or a two-year program, concluded with a final paper based on one year of independent research.{{sfn|NUFFIC|2013|pages=9–10}} Both can lead to a Ph.D., usually achieved in 3 years within a doctoral programme.{{sfn|NUFFIC|2013|pages=9–10}} Polytechnics (10 institutions){{sfn |Atuahene, Ansah|2013|p=2}} offer a vocational education. They propose 3-year curricula, leading to a Higher National Diploma(HND). The students have then the possibility to follow a special 18-month program to achieve a Bachelor of Technology degree. Ghana also possesses many "colleges of education", public or private.{{sfn |Atuahene, Ansah|2013|p=2}} They are usually specialized in one field (colleges of agriculture p.e) or in one work-training (Nursing training colleges, teacher training colleges, p.e).{{sfn |Atuahene, Ansah|2013|p=2}} New tertiary education graduates have to serve one year within the National Service. Participants can serve in one of the eight following sectors: Agriculture, Health, Education, Local Government, Rural Development, Military and Youth Programmes ===Grading system=== Ghana’s grading system is different at every point in education. Through the kindergarten to the junior high, every grade a student gains is written in terms of numbers instead of alphabets. There is no system of pluses and minuses (no "1+"’s or "6+"’s as grades). '''Senior high school''' Until 2007, Senior secondary High school ended with the Senior Secondary School Certificate(SSSC).{{sfn|NUFFIC|2013|page=5}} Its grading system went from A to E.{{sfn|NUFFIC|2013|page=11}} In 2007, the SSSC was replaced by the West African Secondary School Certificate Examination ([[WASSCE]]).{{sfn|NUFFIC|2013|page=5}} The WASSCE grading system adds numbers to the letters, offering a larger scale of evaluation. In both systems, each grade refers to a certain number of points. In order to join a Bachelor degree program, applicants are usually asked not to exceed 24 points at their WASSCE/SSSC.{{sfn|NUFFIC|2013|page=11}} {|class="wikitable" |+Senior Secondary High School grading system{{sfn|NUFFIC|2013|page=11}} |- !SSSCE grades(before 2007), [in points] !WASSCE grades(since 2007),[in points] !Description |- |A[1]||A1[1]||Excellent |- |B[2]||B2[2]||Very good |- |C[3]||B3[3]||Good |- |D[4]||C4[4]||Credit |- |x||C5[5]||Credit |- |x||C6[6]||Credit |- |E||D7||Pass |- |x||E8||Pass |- |F||F9||Fail |- |} '''Tertiary education''' The grading system varies from institution to institution.{{sfn|NUFFIC|2013|page=11}} Almost all the tertiary institutions are based on the Grade Point Average (G.P.A) as a way of assessing whether a student is failing or passing. But individual schools have their own way of calculating GPA's, because of their individualized marking schemes. For example, a mark of 80 may be an A in a school but may be an A+ in another school. == Private Education and Private-Public Partnership In Ghana == The Ghanaian government cannot bear the costs in Education alone, thus private institutions and individuals build and operate private institutions to help the government deal with costs in education.{{Cite journal|last=Nsiah-Peprah|first=Y.|date=2004-01-01|title=Assessment of the role of private schools in the development of education in Ghana. A study of the Kumasi Metropolis|url=https://www.ajol.info/index.php/just/article/view/32917|journal=Journal of Science and Technology (Ghana)|language=en|volume=24|issue=2|pages=54–75|issn=0855-0395}} The Ghanian government is incapable of providing increasing educational services.Adoma, K., & Yeboah, S. (2014). Privatization of Education in Ghana: An International Comparison with the Dutch Educational System. ''International Journal of Innovative Research and Development'', ''3''(1). Education in Ghana has therefore become a shared effort by both the government and private institution, in order to make up for financial inefficiency, on the side of the government and make education accessible to all. There is a call for public-private partnership in education in most developing countries due to the growing involvement of private actors in education.{{Cite journal|last=Akyeampong|first=Kwame|date=2009|title=Public–private partnership in the provision of basic education in Ghana: challenges and choices|journal=Compare: A Journal of Comparative and International Education|volume=39|issue=2|pages=135–149|via=Taylor and Francis Online|doi=10.1080/03057920902750368}} The structure of this joint effort by the public and private sectors to address the problem of financing education at the basic or elementary level is as follows''':''' {| class="wikitable" |- !Agency ! href="Gross Enrollment Ratio" |Role |- |'''Public Sector:'''|| |- |Central Government |Responsible for remuneration of teachers who teach in public schools Responsible for the provision of free textbooks for pupils in public schools, from primary 1 to 6 Responsible for the provision of supplies, equipment and tool sneeded for basic public schools |- |District AssembliesProvide educational infrastructure |-'''Private Sector:''' |- |'''Private Sector:''' | |- |Parents |Responsible for payment of textbook user fees for children at the Junior High School level

Responsible for furniture, food, and transportation to and from school

|- |Communities |Classroom maintenance and provision |- |Churches and NGOs||Provide basic school buildings and structure, furniture |- |- |Private Institutions/Individuals |Founding and managing private schools solely operated by founders, without any financial or infrastructural help from the government |- |International Organizations||Provide financial and technical assistance for basic education in Ghana |}Private involvement in education has led to establishment of private schools and institutions which have affected education in Ghana.{{Cite journal|last=University of Birmingham|date=April 2014|title=The role and impact of private schools in developing countries - Bibliography and literature reviews|url=https://www.odi.org/sites/odi.org.uk/files/odi-assets/publications-opinion-files/10146.pdf|journal=Institute of Education, University of London}} Private primary and junior high schools in Ghana outnumber the public schools in Ghana.{{Cite web|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2013/05/30/private-schools-for-the-poor/|title=Private schools for the poor|website=Foreign Policy|language=en|access-date=2018-04-12}} 74.7% of 779 primary and junior secondary schools were identified as private schools in a census conducted in the Ga district of Ghana, while the remaining 25.3% were identified as government or public schools.{{Cite journal|last=Tooley|first=James|last2=Dixon|first2=Pauline|last3=Amuah|first3=Isaac|date=2007-07-01|title=Private and Public Schooling in Ghana: A Census and Comparative Survey|journal=International Review of Education|language=en|volume=53|issue=4|pages=389–415|doi=10.1007/s11159-007-9042-3|issn=0020-8566|bibcode=2007IREdu..53..389T}} Over the past 20 years, private school attending students in developing countries, increased by 11%; from 11% to 22%.''Abdul-Hamid, Husein; Baum, Donald Rey; De Brular, Laura Lewis; Lusk-Stover, Oni; Tettey, Leslie Ofosu. 2017. Ghana Engaging the Private Sector in Education : SABER Pilot Country Report 2015. World Bank, Washington, DC. © World Bank. https://openknowledge.worldbank.org/handle/10986/28258 License: CC BY 3.0 IGO.'' ==Governance== ===Administration=== Education in Ghana is under the responsibility of the Ministry of Education. Implementation of policies is assumed by its numerous agencies: The Ghana Education Service (GES) is responsible for the coordination of national education policy on pre-tertiary education. It shares this task with three autonomous bodies, the National Inspectorate Board (NIB), the National Teaching Council (NTC) and the National Council for Curriculum and Assessment (NCCA).{{cite web | url=http://pdf.usaid.gov/pdf_docs/pnadz599.pdf | title=Ghana Education Decentralization Project (GEDP): Operational Framework for National Teaching Council (NTC) | publisher=Ministry of Education | date=February 2012 | accessdate=20 July 2014}} The terminal examinations of the pre-tertiary education are conducted by the West African Examination Council (National Office, Ghana): it includes the BECE and the WASCCE but also foreign professional examination.{{cite web | url=http://www.ghanawaec.org/EXAMS/Others.aspx | title=About the WASSCE | publisher=WASSCE | accessdate=20 July 2014}} The Council for Technical and vocational education and Training is dedicated to the management of [[Vocational Education|TVET]]. The collection and analysis of educational data is handled by the Education Management Information System (EMIS). Policies are implemented in cooperation with the local offices: Ghana is divided into 10 regional and 138 local offices. The Ghana Education Decentralization Project (GEDP), launched in 2010 and ended in 2012, has increased the influence of local authorities over management, finance, and operational issues when it comes to educational matters. ===Financing=== The Ghanaian State has dedicated 23% of its expenditure to education in 2010.{{cite web | url=http://www.uis.unesco.org/StatisticalCapacityBuilding/Workshop%20Documents/Education%20workshop%20dox/2012%20Addis%20Ababa/Country%20presentations/Ghana_EFB_Presentation_21Nov2011.pptx | title=Education Finance Brief, Ghana | publisher=Ministry of Education | date=November 2012 | accessdate=24 July 2014}} More than 90% of this budget is spent by the Ministry of Education and its agencies: Primary education (31% of the expenditure) and tertiary education(21,6%) are the most provided. The expenditures are partly funded by donors. Among them can be found the [[World Bank]], the United States (through the [[USAID]]), the United Kingdom(through the [[DfID]]) and the European Union.{{cite web | url=http://ceid.educ.cam.ac.uk/publications/WP16.pdf | title=The financing and outcomes of Education in Ghana | publisher=University of Cambridge | accessdate=13 June 2014 |author1=Nii Moi Thompson |author2=Leslie Casely-Hayford | pages=16–17}} Their participation is usually project-focused and granted under certain condition, giving them a certain influence. This influence can provoke debates when it comes to key-reforms: For the FCUBE project, the World Bank imposed book charges in primary schools and reduced feeding and boarding costs in secondary schools. Facing criticisms, the Bank insisted on the “strong domestic ownership” of the reform and the necessity to ensure “cost recovery”. Between 2005 and 2012, the part of donors in the Ghanaian budget has fallen from 8.5 to 2.5% of the total education expenditure. ===Teacher training=== Colleges of Education are the main teacher training institutions: There are 38 public and 3 private "CoE" split in then 10 Ghanaian regions.{{cite web | url=http://sgo.sagepub.com/content/4/2/2158244014529781.full-text.pdf+html | title=Teacher Education in Ghana: A contemporary synopsis and matters arising | publisher=SageOpen | date=April 2014 | accessdate=25 July 2014 |author1=Kwame Bediako Asare |author2=Seth Kofi Nti }} They offer a three-year curriculum that leads to the Diploma in Basic Education(DBE). The education is described as “uniform” and with a “national focus” even if CoE are present in every Ghanaian regions. The final examinations granting the DBE are conducted by the public University of Cape Coast’s Institute of Education. The holders of the DBE are allowed to teach at every level of the Basic education(Kindergarten, Primary school, Junior Secondary School). Apart from the Colleges of education, two universities (Cape Coast and Winneba) train teachers. A specific four-year bachelor's degree allows to teach in any pre-tertiary education (most graduates choosing secondary education).{{cite web | url=http://www.sussex.ac.uk/cie/projects/completed/tpa/ghana | title=Research overview: Teacher preparation and continuing professional development in Africa (TPA) | publisher=University of Sussex | date=2008 | accessdate=25 July 2014}} A specific master's degree is needed for teaching in CoE. Universities also offer to DBE graduate a two-curriculum granting the right to teach in secondary education. Distance education is also possible: the programme lasts four years and leads to the Untrained Teacher’s Diploma in Basic Education (UTDBE). It was introduced to increase the number of basic education teachers in the rural area. Serving teacher can also benefit of continuing education (in-service training, cluster). ==Public action and Policies== ===Adult literacy, non-formal education=== '''''Public action against illiteracy''''' started more than 50 years ago in Ghana. Initiated in the 1940s by the British rulers, its eradication was raised to top-priority at the independence in 1957.{{cite web | url=http://www.odi.org/sites/odi.org.uk/files/odi-assets/publications-opinion-files/4070.pdf | title=National Functional Literacy Programme (NFLP) | publisher=Overseas Development Institute | date=2005 | accessdate=23 July 2014}} Political unrests however limited political actions to sporadic short-term programmes, until 1987 and the creation of the Non-Formal Education Division (NFED), whose goal was to eliminate illiteracy by 2000. After a convincing try in 2 regions, the Functional Literacy Skills Project (FLSP) was expanded to the whole country in 1992. In 2000, the programme was taken over by the National Functional Literacy Programme (FNLP), which is still active nowadays. Those programmes focus on gender and geographical inequalities. Women and people living in rural area are their main targets.{{cite web | url=http://datatopics.worldbank.org/hnp/files/edstats/GHAgmrpro07.pdf | title=Ghana non-formal Education | publisher=World Bank | date=2008 | accessdate=23 July 2014 | author=Francis Owusu-Mensah}} In 2004, there were 1238 “Literacy centers”, situated mostly in non-urban area. The successive projects led to statistical progress. In 1997, 64% of women were illiterate for 38% of men, for a global literacy rate of 54%. In 2010, women literacy was 65% and the global literacy rate had increased to 71.5%. Academics, however, pointed out the insufficient progress of women literacy and the difficulty for graduated to upkeep their new skills. {| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto;" |+Evolution of literacy rate over time{{cite web | url=http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0021/002174/217409e.pdf | title=Adult and youth literacy: National, regional and global trends, 1985-2015 | publisher=UNESCO-UIS | date=June 2013 | accessdate=25 September 2014|page=51 (Table 6)}} ! rowspan="2" | x ! colspan="3" | Adult literacy(15+) ! colspan="3" | Youth literacy (15-24) |- | {{abbr|Av|Average}} | {{abbr|M|Male}} | {{abbr|F|Female}} | {{abbr|Av|Average}} | {{abbr|M|Male}} | {{abbr|F|Female}} |- | 2000 | 57.9 | 66.4 | 49.8 | 70.7 | 75.9 | 65.4 |- | 2010 | 71.5 | 78.3 | 65.3 | 85.7 | 88.3 | 83.2 |- | 2015(projection) | 76.3 | 81.5 | 71.0 | 90.6 | 91.3 | 89.9 |} '''''Other forms of non-formal education''''' are also conducted by the NFED: "Life-skills training" (Family planning, hygiene, prevention on AIDS) targeting adolescent and young mother, "Occupational skills training" for unemployed adults or "civil awareness" seminars (on civil rights and duties) addressed to illiterate adults. ===Development of technical and vocational education=== There is an informal education sector in Ghana, which is usually made up of which is usually made up of training, vocational, and technical institutions. These training, technical, and vocational institutions are informal because they do not take place in a classroom setting; these trainings usually take the form of apprenticeship, direct learning, practice, and supervision from trainers. There is usually no official or recognized certification or qualifications given to trainees.{{Cite journal|last=Sherry K. Amedorme, Yesuenyeagbe A.K. Fiagbe|date=June 2013|title=Challenges Facing Technical And Vocational Education in Ghana|url=http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.307.5235&rep=rep1&type=pdf|journal=International Journal of Scientific & Technology Research|volume= 2|pages=256|via=}} Developing technical and vocational education and training(TVET) is considered a priority by central authorities in order to tackle poverty and unemployment.{{cite web | url=http://www.gesci.org/assets/files/COTVET%20report.pdf | title=From prejudice to prestige: Vocational education and training in Ghana | publisher=Council for Technical and Vocational Education and Training (COTVET)| date=2011 | pages=19–35 |accessdate=28 May 2014}}{{cite web | url=http://www.oecd.org/dev/emea/40577770.pdf | title=Ghana country profile | publisher=OECD | date=2008 | accessdate=25 July 2014 | pages=341–342}} TVET in Ghana face numerous problems: low completion rate (in 2011, 1.6% of the population got a TVET degree whereas 11% of the population followed a TVET programme), « poorly trained instructor » and lack of infrastructure. The Ghanaian industry also criticizes the lack of practical experience of the formal graduates and the lack of basic skills(reading, writing) of informal apprentices. In 2008, the OECD reproached the opacity of the qualifications framework and the multiplication of worthless TVET certificates. The official council for TVET observed that informal or graduated TVET students struggle to find a job, and then have to deal with income volatility or low wages. TVET, therefore, suffer from a poor reputation among students, parents and employers.{{cite web | url=http://www.apjce.org/files/APJCE_12_2_67_77.pdf | title=Challenges facing technical institute graduates in practical skills acquisition in the upper East region of Ghana | publisher=Asia-Pacific Journal of Cooperative Education (APJCE) | accessdate=25 July 2014 | author=Adam Dasmani | page=2}} In 2005, a micro-credit system in favor of low-skilled unemployed youth was implemented(STEP programme). In 2006, the Council for Technical and Vocational Education and Training(COTVET) was created and entrusted with the mission of coordination "TVET policies" in Ghana. The council introduced a National Youth Found in 2006, and proposed a TVET qualifications framework in 2010. It tries besides to frame the informal sector through a National Apprenticeship Programme(NAP) and to strengthen guidance and counselling at basic education level.{{cite web | url=http://www.cotvet.org/new/downloads/Skills%20Advocate%20newsletter2013_Q.pdf | title=Skills advocate: Quarterly COTVET newsletter | publisher=COTVET | date=March 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140809024837/http://www.cotvet.org/new/downloads/Skills%20Advocate%20newsletter2013_Q.pdf|archivedate=9 August 2014|deadurl=y|accessdate=9 September 2015}} Impacts are, however, difficult to assess :{{sfn|Ministry of Education|2013|page=65}} TVET in Ghana is still hard to grasp. 90% is informal and both the public and private sectors are highly segmented.{{sfn|Ministry of Education|2013|page=65}} The ministry of Education itself admits its incapacity to provide a global statistic view of the TVET sector in Ghana.{{sfn|Ministry of Education|2013|page=65}} ===Equity in access to tertiary education=== With the rise of enrollment in secondary education, competition for joining higher education institution has globally increased: In 2001, the university of Ghana had admitted 96% of the relevant applications it had received. In 2011, this acceptance rate had fallen to 52%.{{sfn |Atuahene, Ansah|2013|loc=fig. 1 (p. 3)}} This increasing selectivity highlights inequalities in Ghana regarding Education: Being a woman{{sfn |Atuahene, Ansah|2013|p=fig. 3(p. 4)}} or living in a rural area{{cite book | title=Change and transformation in Ghana's publicly funded universities. Partnership for Higher Education in Africa |author1=Manuh T. |author2=Sulley G. |author3=Budu J. | publisher=Oxford, UK: James Currey and Accra | year=2007 |url=http://www.bc.edu/content/dam/files/research_sites/cihe/inhea/Manuh_etal_2007_Ghana_Public_Univ.pdf}}{{cite web | url=http://www.modernghana.com/news/8474/1/addae-mensah-says-inequalities-in-basic-education-.html | title=Addae-Mensah says inequalities in basic education system is dangerous | publisher=Modern Ghana | date=23 February 2000 | accessdate=23 May 2014}} can reduce the chance of reaching tertiary Education. Socioeconomic status is also a factor of exclusion, as studying at the highest level is expensive: Public universities have no tuition fee but usually demand payment for other charges: registration fee, technology fee, examination fee, academic facility user fee, medical services fee.{{sfn |Atuahene, Ansah|2013|p=9}} These charges can lead to [[self-censorship]] behaviors, some students choosing, for instance, Teacher Training Colleges (where students can receive stipends) instead of joining a university.{{sfn |Atuahene, Ansah|2013|p=9}} Policies has been developed to limit those inequalities: Some universities have, for instance, lowered their minimum entry requirement or created scholarship for students from the "less-endowed secondary school".{{cite web | url=http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/NewsArchive/artikel.php?ID=53790 | title=University of Ghana to admit students from less endowed SSS | publisher=Ghana Web | date=March 2004 | accessdate=23 May 2014}}{{cite news | url=http://www.modernghana.com/news/38696/1/knust-implements-scheme-for-admitting-students-fro.html | title=KNUST implements scheme for admitting students from less endowed schools | date=August 2003 | accessdate=23 May 2014}} A "Girls Education unit" has been created by the government within the Ghana Education Service, in order to reduce gender-biased disparities: The unit tries to tackle the problem at its source, focusing on the "basic Education" to avoid high female school drop-out from {{abbr|JHS|Junior High School}} to {{abbr|SHS|Senior High School}}.{{cite web | url=http://www.ges.gov.gh/?q=node/13 | title=Girl's Education | publisher=Ghana Education Service | accessdate=24 May 2014}} Progresses have been made: The proportion of girls in Higher Education has increased from 25%(1999) to 32%(2005).{{sfn |Atuahene, Ansah|2013|pp=5-6}}Yet gender still generates inequality, for numerous reasons: Hostile school environment, priority given to the boys in poor families, perpetuation of "gender roles" ("a woman belongs to the household"), early customary marriages, teenage pregnancy...{{sfn |Atuahene, Ansah|2013|pp=5-6}} Higher education is more heavily male than female and more wealthy than poor: {{quotation|HE in Ghana is disproportionately ‘consumed’ by the richest 20% of the population. Male students from the highest income quintile (Q5) are more than seven times more likely to enter and successfully complete HE than those from the poorest quintile (Q1). The situation is even more precarious for the female category where students come from only the richest 40% of the population.|World Bank 2011|[http://www-wds.worldbank.org/external/default/WDSContentServer/WDSP/IB/2013/06/27/000442464_20130627122630/Rendered/PDF/597550Revised00elivery0March0902011.pdf" Education in Ghana: Improving equity, efficiency, and accountability of Education service delivery]}} ===ICT in education=== [[File:Wikimedia Outreach in Ghana 6.jpeg|thumb|right|Some [[University of Ghana]] students engaged in a Wikipedia outreach]] Computer technology used for teaching and learning began to receive governments’ attention in the past decade. The ICT in Education Policy of Ghana requires the use of ICT for teaching and learning at all levels of the education system. Attempts have been made by the [[Ministry of Education (Ghana)|Ministry of Education]] to support institutions in the teaching of ICT literacy. Most secondary, and some basic, schools have computer laboratories. Despite the interest in ICT, computers are very limited and are often carried around to ensure that they do not get stolen.{{cite web|last1=Marshall|first1=Lillie|title=Fun Facts about Ghana's School Systems|url=http://www.aroundtheworldl.com/2010/02/23/fun-facts-about-ghanas-school-system/|website=Around the World L|accessdate=17 May 2016}} A recent study on the Pedagogical integration of ICTs from 2009-2011 in 10 Ghanaian schools indicates that there is a gap between the policy directives and actual practices in schools. The emphasis of the official curricula is on the development of students’ skills in operating ICTs but not necessarily using the technology as a means of learning subjects other than ICTs. The study also found that the Ministry of Education is currently at the stage of deployment of ICT resources for developing the needed ICT literacy required for integration into teaching/learning.K. D. Mereku, I. Yidana, W. H. K. HORDZI, I. Tete-Mensah; Williams, J. B. (2009). Pedagogical integration of ICT: Ghana report. [http://www.ernwaca.org/panaf/pdf/phase-1/Ghana-PanAf_Report.pdf] {{clear}} ==See also== {{portal|Ghana}} * [[List of universities in Ghana]] * [[List of senior secondary schools in Ghana]] ==Notes== {{reflist|30em}} ==References== * {{cite web | ref=harv | url=http://www.moe.gov.gh/docs/ESPR%202013%20Final%20August.pdf | title=Education Sector Performance Report | publisher=Ministry of Education, Republic of Ghana | author=Ministry of Education|date=July 2013 | accessdate=27 May 2014 }} * {{cite web | url=http://sgo.sagepub.com/content/3/3/2158244013497725 | title=A Descriptive Assessment of Higher Education Access, Participation, Equity, and Disparity in Ghana | publisher=SageOpen | date=23 July 2013 | accessdate=23 May 2014 | author=Atuahene, Ansah|ref=harv}} * {{cite web | url=http://www.nuffic.nl/en/library/country-module-ghana.pdf | title=Country Module: Ghana | author=NUFFIC|publisher=Netherlands Organisation for International Cooperation in Higher Education | date=January 2013 | accessdate=25 May 2014| ref=harv}} * {{cite web | url=http://www.ijhssnet.com/journals/Vol_2_No_4_Special_Issue_February_2012/15.pdf | title= Restructuring Vocational and Technical Education in Ghana: The Role of Leadership Development| date=February 2012 | accessdate=7 February 2018| author=Boateng, Christina| ref=harv}} ==External links== '''State-Institutions''' * [http://www.moe.gov.gh/ Ministry of Education]- Responsible for initiating, formulating, coordinating and reviewing all education policies in Ghana * [http://www.moe.gov.gh/site/agencies/ List of the "Agencies" attached to the Ministry of Education] - includes the Ghana Education Service (GES), the National Accreditation Board (NAB), the National Council for Tertiary Education(NCTE)... '''Data and reports from external institutions''' * [http://www.nuffic.nl/en/library/country-module-ghana.pdf "Country Module: Ghana", NUFFIC(2013)] - Overview of the Educational system by the Netherlands Organization for International Cooperation in Higher Education. * [http://www.unevoc.unesco.org/worldtvetdatabase1.php?ct=GHA "Vocational Education" in Ghana, UNESCO-UNEVOC (2012)] - Overview of the vocational Education system * [http://www.unesco.org/new/fileadmin/MULTIMEDIA/HQ/ED/pdf/EDUCATION_IN_GHANA_A_FACT_SHEET.pdf "Education in Ghana: A fact sheet", UNICEF(2012)] - A 2-page analysis backed by numerous data. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20140527212803/http://www.adeanet.org/adeaPortal/publications/wgesa/en/doc/ghana/contents.htm Review of Education Sector Analysis in Ghana 1987-1998, WGESA] {{Ghana topics}} {{Education in Africa}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Education In Ghana}} [[Category:Education in Ghana| ]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2017}} {{Use British English|date=January 2017}} {{notability|Music|date=February 2016}} '''Feargus Hetherington''' (born 1979 in [[Scotland]]) is a [[violin]]ist and [[violist]] based in [[Glasgow]]. He has performed from an early age throughout [[Scotland]] and abroad. He arranges music, teaches and presents music workshops and seminars.
==Studies, teaching and coaching==
Hetherington studied at the [[Royal Conservatoire of Scotland]] and the [[Cleveland Institute of Music]], [[Ohio]], supported by a [[Cleveland Institute of Music]] Scholarship and a Caird Trust Travel Scholarship. He attended summer short courses abroad including the Starling-DeLay Symposium on Violin Studies at the [[Juilliard School]] and the Aria International Summer School. In 2001/2002 he was leader of the [[National Youth Orchestra of Scotland]] as they toured in [[Scotland]], The [[Netherlands]] and [[Germany]]. From 2012 - 2014 he has participated in Total Immersion Seminars with [[Joseph Swensen]],<ref>{{cite web|last1=Swensen|first1=Joseph|title=Total Immersion|url=http://habitat4music.org/total-immersion/|website=Habitat4Music|accessdate=11 February 2016}}</ref> in [[Vermont]], USA, supported by the [[Musicians Benevolent Fund]] and [[Creative Scotland]] (twice).<ref>{{cite web|title=Awards Made - April 2012|url=http://www.creativescotland.com/__data/assets/excel_doc/0003/25284/Awards-Made-April-2012.xls|publisher=Creative Scotland|accessdate=13 January 2016|format=Excel}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Awards Made - April 2013|url=http://www.creativescotland.com/__data/assets/excel_doc/0006/25296/Awards-Made-April-2013.xls |publisher=Creative Scotland|accessdate=13 January 2016|format=Excel}}</ref>
Hetherington teaches violin,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.st-andrews.ac.uk/music/people/teachers/|title=Instrumental and vocal teachers|publisher= University of St Andrews |accessdate=8 January 2016}}</ref> viola and chamber music<ref>{{cite web|title=Scholarship Ensembles|url=http://www.st-andrews.ac.uk/music/perform/instrumental/scholarship%20ensembles/|website=www.st-andrews.ac.uk|publisher=University of St Andrews|accessdate=20 January 2016}}</ref> at the [[University of St Andrews]], Scotland, where he also coaches the St Andrews Chamber Orchestra.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.st-andrews.ac.uk/music/perform/instrumental/chamberorchestra/|title=St Andrews Chamber Orchestra |publisher= University of St Andrews |accessdate=8 January 2016}}</ref>
==Performance: solo and duo==
Hetherington has given unaccompanied recitals featuring works by major classical composers and by contemporary Scottish composers, some of which he has premiered.<ref>{{cite web|title=Macpherson’s Cave: The Sound of Rooms|url=https://edinburghfestival.list.co.uk/event/10006758-macphersons-cave-the-sound-of-rooms/|website=The List|accessdate=23 March 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iainmatheson.co.uk/works.php#chamber/|title= Iain Matheson - Works - Chamber - Scottish Composer & Musician|publisher=Iain Matheson |accessdate=8 January 2016}}</ref> He has performed many of the major concertos with Scottish orchestras including [[Violin Concerto (Tchaikovsky)]],<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Tumulty|first1=Michael|title=Kelvin Ensemble/Edinburgh University Chamber Orchestra|journal=The Herald|date=10 February 2003}}</ref> [[Violin Concerto (Elgar)]],<ref>{{cite web|title=New Edinburgh Orchestra Past Concerts|url=http://www.newedinburghorchestra.org.uk/past-concerts.php|website=New Edinburgh Orchestra|accessdate=16 March 2016}}</ref> [[Max Bruch|Bruch]]'s [[Scottish Fantasy]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gos.org.uk/|title=Glasgow Orchestral Society|publisher= |at="Concerts" section |accessdate=8 January 2016}}</ref> the [[Violin Concerto No. 1 (Bruch)]] with,<ref name="Heisenberg"/> and ''Autumn'' from [[Vivaldi]]'s ''[[The Four Seasons (Vivaldi)|The Four Seasons]]''. Hetherington had first performed this with the Scottish Bach Consort in 1996.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Magee|first1=Henry|title=Scottish Bach Consort|journal=The Herald|date=17 June 1996|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/12116219.Music__Scottish_Bach_Consort__Kelvinside_Hillhead_Church__Glasgow/|accessdate=5 February 2016}}</ref>
Hetherington has collaborated with a number of pianists. During a short tour in October 2014 he was interviewed and performed on ''Classics Unwrapped'' on [[BBC Radio Scotland]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p029764f|series=Classics Unwrapped |date= 21 October 2014 |title=Feargus Hetherington and Gavin Brady - Interview and Live session|work=BBC Radio Scotland |accessdate=8 January 2016}}</ref> A much earlier review of the same duo noted that Hetherington could spin "a most beautiful tone ... floating a soft high note as pure and delicate as a thread of goassamer".<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Critic|first1=Music|title=Musical duo a heavenly match|journal=The Courier|date=28 April 2000}}</ref> A review of the [[Brahms]] Viola Sonatas at [[Edinburgh Festival Fringe]] in 2014 noted 'virtuosic technique and shrewd musical artistry".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/arts_ents/13175417.Fringe_Classical__Review/|title=Fringe Classical: Review|work=Herald Scotland |accessdate=8 January 2016}}</ref> His tour of eight concerts throughout the UK in 2013 with [[Olga Gorelik]] ended with a "breathless audience" at an [[Edinburgh Festival Fringe]] concert, for a programme on 'Elgar and his Contemporaries'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.edinburghspotlight.com/2013/08/fringe-review-elgar-and-his-contemporaries/|title=Edinburgh - FRINGE REVIEW – Elgar and his Contemporaries |publisher=Edinburgh Spotlight |accessdate=8 January 2016}}</ref> A review of their Scottish tour the previous year indicated that "this is a partnership which will go far ..."<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Ross|first1=D. James|title=A lunchtime treat|journal=Nairnshire Telegraph|date=19 April 2012}}</ref> A series of concerts with Edward Cohen following the programme format used during 'The Golden Age of Violin' (1920 - 1940) culminated with a West End Festival concert in Glasgow<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.westendfestival.co.uk/updates/recital-from-the-golden-age/|title=West End Festival 2015|publisher= |accessdate=8 January 2016}}</ref> and two concerts at the 2015 Edinburgh Festival Fringe. For more than a decade Hetherington has performed in the concert series 'Music for a Summer Afternoon' in the [[Cathedral of the Isles]], [[Isle of Cumbrae]].<ref name="cumbraecathedralfriends_2015">{{cite web |url=http://cumbraecathedralfriends.com/page19.html |title= Concert in the Cathedral, 5 April 2015| publisher= The Friends of the Cathedral of the Isles |accessdate=10 January 2016}}</ref> Since 2013 he has toured regularly with [[Opera Bohemia]]'s <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.operabohemia.co.uk/madame-butterfly-2//|title=Madame Butterfly|publisher=operabohemia.co.uk |accessdate=8 January 2016}}</ref> chamber version of [[Madame Butterfly]] (solo violin with piano) for small communities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.whfp.com/2015/05/12/madame-butterfly-in-kyleakin-hall/|title=‘Madame Butterfly’ in Kyleakin hall|author=Michael Russell|work=West Highland Free Press |accessdate=8 January 2016}}</ref> Concerts abroad include [[New York City|New York]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Feargus Hetherington and Steven Beck|url=http://www.timeout.com/newyork/music/feargus-hetherington-and-steven-beck-wmp-concert-hall-june-25-2010|website=Time Out|accessdate=12 March 2016}}</ref> [[Poland]],<ref>{{cite web|title=KONCERT KAMERALNY|url=http://www.filharmonia.rzeszow.pl/repertuar/art,264.html|website=filharmonia|accessdate=12 March 2016}}</ref> [[Germany]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Konzert Facetten mit dem Duo Hetherington/Brady|url=http://www.musikschule-friedrichsdorf.de/event/konzert-facetten-mit-dem-duo-hetheringtonbrady/|website=Musikschule Friedrichdorf|accessdate=12 March 2016}}</ref> [[Sweden]]<ref>{{cite web|title=musik-i-sommarkvall|url=http://www.svenskakyekan.se/karlskrona/musik-isommarkvall|website=svenskakyrkan|accessdate=15 March 2016}}</ref> and a tour in [[Ireland]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Frevo Quartet in Dublin|url=http://www.matthewmcallister.com/blog/frevo_quartet_in_dublin/|website=Matthew McAllister}}</ref> Hetherington has been involved with singers,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Robertson|first1=Stuart|title=Feargus|url=https://www.blipfoto.com/entry/3942319|website=Blipfoto|accessdate=20 March 2016}}</ref> in innovative art projects,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pittenweemartsfestival.co.uk/tim-fitzpatrick.html|title=Tim Fitzpatrick|publisher=www.pittenweemartsfestival.co.uk |accessdate=8 January 2016}}</ref> new violin projects <ref>{{cite web|title=Classical review: Maelasta|url=http://www.scotsman.com/lifestyle/classical-review-maelasta-1-782419|website=The Scotsman|accessdate=21 March 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=The Sycamore Sings: Wilfred Owen Violin|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p0243xct/p02443yx|website=BBC Scotland|accessdate=21 March 2016}}</ref> and exhibitions<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iotaarts.space/music-sound-2/|title=Music Sound|work=Unlimited Studios |accessdate=8 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iotaarts.space/feargus-hetherington/|title=Feargus Hetherington|work=Unlimited Studios |accessdate=8 January 2016}}</ref>
==Chamber music and orchestra==
Since 2015 Hetherington has performed with the newly formed Kentigern Quartet,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.whatsonglasgow.co.uk/event/025109-friends-of-glasgow-cathedral-summer-music-series/|title=Friends of Glasgow Cathedral Summer Music Series |work=What's On Glasgow}}</ref> based in [[Glasgow]] and since 2010 has led The Auriga Strings in Wiltshire.<ref>{{cite web|title=Feargus Hetherington under Players/Violins on|url=http://www.theaurigastrings.co.uk/violins.html|website=www.theaurigastrings.co.uk |accessdate=8 January 2016}}</ref> He is a former member of a number of chamber groups including Symposia,<ref name=SYMPOSIA>{{cite web|url=http://www.symposiamusic.co.uk/aboutus.htm|title=About Us|publisher=SYMPOSIA |accessdate=8 January 2016}}</ref> The Frevo Quartet<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tokafi.com/news/cd-feature-frevo-quartet-histoire-du-tango/|title=CD Feature - Frevo Quartet: "Histoire du Tango"|website=www.tokafi.com}}</ref> and the Roxburgh Quartet.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.strathearnmusicsociety.btck.co.uk/Reviews/Review-RoxburghQuartet|title= Review - Roxburgh Quartet|publisher=Strathearn Music Society |accessdate=8 January 2016}}</ref> As a freelance musician Hetherington has performed with many ensembles and orchestras including the [[Scottish Chamber Orchestra]] with whom he toured in Germany in 2008. Ensemble leadership included the Heisenberg Ensemble (guest leader since 2010),<ref name = "Heisenberg">{{cite news|title=Music Reviews by Garry Fraser|last1=Fraser|first1=Garry|work=The Courier|date=12 March 2015|location=Dundee, UK}}, cited in {{cite web |url= http://www.heisenbergensemble.co.uk/review.html |title=Reviews |publisher=Heisenberg Ensemble |first= |last= |website=heisenbergensemble.co.uk |year=2015 |accessdate=8 January 2016}}</ref> a thirteen-piece professional ensemble for [[Benjamin Britten]]'s Opera [[Albert Herring]].,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.operascotland.org/tour/2701/Albert+Herring+2014|title=Albert Herring 2014 - Tour|author=|publisher=Opera Scotland |accessdate=8 January 2016}}</ref> [[Opera Bohemia]]'s [[Eugene Onegin]]([[Tchaikovsky]])<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.operabohemia.co.uk/eugene-onegin-3/|title=Eugene Onegin|publisher=operabohemia.co.uk |accessdate=8 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=REVIEW -- Opera Bohemia Perform Eugene Onegin|url=http://www.inverclydenow.com/news/features/11689-review-opera-bohemia-perform-eugene-onegin|website=Inverclydenow|accessdate=23 March 2016}}</ref> and was violinist in the ensemble for ''Hirda'', a Shetland Opera.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Molleson|first1=Kate|title=Hirda review – a well-drawn chamber opera plays to the home crowd|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/nov/29/hirda-review-noise-opera|website=The Guardian|accessdate=20 March 2016}}</ref> He has led orchestras and ensembles, including the City of Glasgow Symphony Orchestra, for many major choral works including the [[Messiah (Handel)]], [[The Seasons (Haydn)]], ''[[Elgar]]'s [[The Apostles (Elgar)|The Apostles]]'', [[Elgar]]'s ''[[The Dream of Gerontius]]'', [[The Creation (Haydn)]] and [[A German Requiem (Brahms)]].
==Instruments==
Hetherington performs on contemporary instruments. He was interviewed by the ''[[The Strad|Strad]]'' magazine<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hetherington|first1=Feargus|title=Player Perspectives|journal=The Strad|date=July 2014|volume=125|issue=1491|page=44}}</ref> (July 2014) about his instruments, two of which were made by Neil Kristóf Értz, one in 2001 (now adapted for Baroque repertoire) and the latest in 2007, after [[Stradivari]] c. 1715.
==Workshops==
Hetherington conducted workshops throughout the UK for [[Live Music Now]], and in 2009 gave workshops in Abu Dhabi<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.livemusicnow.org.uk/lmn_news/item/63223/date/2009-06-01/title/ground_breaking_delivery_for_special_needs_children_in_abu_dhabi|title=Ground breaking delivery for special needs children in Abu Dhabi|publisher=livemusicnow.org.uk |accessdate=8 January 2016}}</ref> as part of Abu Dhabi Music and Arts Festival organised by the [[Abu Dhabi Music & Arts Foundation]]. As a member of Symposia,<ref name=SYMPOSIA/> he toured in the UK, US and South Africa, promoting specially composed and recorded music, ''The Farmer's Cheese'', for young people with cochlear implants. In 2013/2014 he was invited by the [[Scottish Ensemble]] to assist in their Music for Change programme in prisons. He has held seminars and concerts in various educational institutions including [[Napier University]] and [[The University of Edinburgh]].
==Discography==
* ''A Highland Ballad'', with pianist Mira Opalińska, released in 2012 by Natural Studio Records<ref>{{cite web|title=CD launch for Feargus Hetherington|url=http://www.classicalmusiciansscotland.com/cd-launch-for-feargus-hetherington/|website=Classical Musicians Scotland|accessdate=15 March 2016}}</ref> * ''The Auriga Strings,'' Brahms String Sextet No. 1 in B Flat, Op. 18 and Strauss Capriccio, Op. 85, 2011, Mooncalf Studio, Wiltshire. * ''Frevo Quartet'', Standing Stones, Natural Studio Records * ''Frevo Quartet'', Histoire du Tango, Natural Studio Records * ''Maelasta'', Natural Studio Records * ''Ness'' by [[Gareth Williams (composer)|Gareth Williams]] recorded on CD "Contemporary Music from Ireland" for the Contemporary Music Centre of Ireland
==Contributor==
* Violinist on Classical Accordionist, Paul Chamberlain's CD, ''Accordion Sensations'' * Violinist on ''Meall a' Bhuiridh'', SPAD CD * Violinist on Sound Track for ''Drift'' (music by Eddie McGuire) recorded Summer 2015 by Vision Mechanics * Violinist in 2007 recording of the ''Rosslyn Motet'' recorded in Rosslyn Chapel
