{{Infobox architect |name = Gaetano Pesce |image = |parents = |nationality = Italian |birth_date = {{birth-date and age|8 November 1939}} |birth_place = [[La Spezia]] |death_date = |significant_building = |practice = architect, designer, educator | }} [[File:Organic building - Osaka.jpg|thumb|Organic building - Osaka]] [[File:Organic building - Gaetano Pesce.jpg|thumb|The Organic Building (1993) in [[Osaka]]]] [[File:Gaetano pesce, up chair 01.JPG|thumb|250px|''Up chair'', designed for C&B Italia (now [[B&B Italia]]), 1969]] [[File:Feltri2.jpg|thumb|250px|''I Feltri'', designed for Cassina (1987)]] [[File:Gaetano pesce, vassoio in resina 03.JPG|thumb|Gaetano pesce, vassoio in resina 03]] [[File:Gaetano Pesce (Michetta).jpg|thumb|Divano modulabile (2005) inspired by [[Michetta]], a typical bread from Milan]]
'''Gaetano Pesce''' (born 8 November 1939) is an Italian [[architect]] and a design pioneer of the 20th century.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/title/century-of-design-design-pioneers-of-the-20th-century/oclc/39637847&referer=brief_results|title=A century of design: design pioneers of the 20th century|last=Sparke|first=Penny|date=1998|isbn=0764151223|language=English}}</ref> Mr. Pesce was born in [[La Spezia]] in 1939, and he grew up in [[Padua]] and [[Florence]].<ref>{{cite news|title=The Collection: Gaetano Pesce Italian, born 1939|url=http://www.moma.org|publisher=MoMA}}</ref> During his 50-year career, Mr. Pesce has worked as an architect, urban planner, and industrial designer.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/title/gaetano-pesce-reinventer-le-monde-sensible/oclc/972263489&referer=brief_results|title=Gaetano Pesce: réinventer le monde sensible|last=Pesce|first=Gaetano|last2=Garnier|first2=Philippe|date=2017|publisher=Buchet Chastel|isbn=9782283028292|location=Paris|language=French}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/title/gaetano-pesce-architetturadesignarte/oclc/875785359&referer=brief_results|title=Gaetano Pesce: architetturadesignarte|last=Vanlaethem|first=France|date=1989|publisher=Idea Books|isbn=887017073X|location=Milano|language=Italian}}</ref> His outlook is considered broad and humanistic, and his work is characterized by an inventive use of color and materials, asserting connections between the individual and society, through art, architecture, and design to reappraise mid-twentieth century modern life .<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/title/gaetano-pesce-architecture-design-art/oclc/636098890&referer=brief_results|title=Gaetano Pesce: architecture, design, art|last=Vanlaethem|first=France|last2=Pesce|first2=Gaetano|last3=Pesce|first3=Gaetano|last4=Pesce|first4=Gaetano|date=1989|publisher=Rizzoli|isbn=0847810860|location=New York|language=English}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/title/gaetano-pesce/oclc/475042307&referer=brief_results|title=Gaetano Pesce|last=Bartolucci|first=Marisa|date=2003|publisher=Chronicle Books|isbn=0811837882|location=San Francisco|language=English}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/title/gaetano-pesce-materia-e-differenza/oclc/187980569&referer=brief_results|title=Gaetano Pesce: materia e differenza|last=Martino|first=Carlo|date=2007|publisher=Marsilio|isbn=9788831789288|location=Venezia|language=Italian}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/title/atomic-dwelling-anxiety-domesticity-and-postwar-architecture/oclc/707965989&referer=brief_results|title=Atomic dwelling: anxiety, domesticity, and postwar architecture|last=Schuldenfrei|first=Robin|date=2012|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9780415676083|location=Abingdon, Oxon; New York|language=English}}</ref>
== Architecture career == Mr. Pesce studied architecture at the [[University of Venice]], with such notable teachers as [[Carlo Scarpa]] and Ernesto Rogers. Between 1958 and 1963, Mr. Pesce participated in Gruppo N, an early collective concerned with programmed art patterned after the [[Bauhaus]]. Since the 1960s, Gaetano Pesce has been known to relate art to the design of interiors, products, and architecture.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Perry|first1=Amy|title=The Legendary Gaetano Pesce on Work and Life|url=http://tmagazine.blogs.nytimes.com|publisher=The New York Times|date=May 8, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/title/gaetano-pesce-some-works-from-1969-1990/oclc/48816683&referer=brief_results|title=Gaetano Pesce: some works from 1969-1990.|last=Pesce|first=Gaetano|last2=Kuramata|first2=Shirō|date=1991|publisher=Gallery·Ma|location=Tokyo}}</ref> The [[New York Times]] critic [[Herbert Muschamp]] described Mr. Pesce as ''"the architectural equivalent of a brainstorm."'' <ref>{{cite news|last1=Muschamp|first1=Herbert|title=It's A Mad Mad Mad Ad World|url=https://www.nytimes.com|publisher=The New York Times|date=October 16, 1994}}</ref> Pesce's well known work includes ''Organic Building'' in [[Osaka]], [[Japan]], a Landmark vertical garden building designed to concealing a complex, computer-controlled hydration system to sustain plant growth, and the interior architecture of the Chiat/Day offices, an early workplace ''village'' modeled after urban life.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Turner|first1=Gavin|last2=Myerson|first2=Jeremy|title=New Workspace, New Culture: Office Design as a Catalyst for Change|date=1998|publisher=Gower Publishing Company|isbn=0566080281|pages=144 pages|url=http://www.gowerpublishing.com}}</ref> Among Mr. Pesce's architecture achievements are [[Les Halles]] ACIH (1979) and [[Parc de la Villette]] (1985), [[Paris, France]], a complex of forms shaped like a running child.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Vanlaethem|first1=France|title=Gaetano Pesce : architecture, design, art|date=1989|publisher=Rizzoli|location=New York|isbn=0847810860|pages=126 pages : illustrations (some color) ; 30 cm}}</ref>
Mr. Pesce's prototypical three-dimensional models and architectural drawings are held in the permanent museum collections of [[MoMA]], [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]], and the [[Cooper-Hewitt]] Smithsonian Design Museum in [[New York City]]; the [[Philadelphia Museum of Art]],PA; [[San Francisco Museum of Art]], [[California]]; [[Victoria and Albert Museum]], [[London]]; [[Vitra Design Museum]], Germany; [[Danish Museum of Art & Design]], [[Copenhagen]]; [[Centre Pompidou]] and [[Musée des Arts Décoratifs, Paris]], [[France]], and the [[Triennale]] Museum, [[Milan, Italy]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Gaetano Pesce|url=https://www.centrepompidou.fr|publisher=The Centre Pompidou}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=UP5 & UP6 Donna (1969): Gaetano Pesce|url=http://www.design-museum.de|publisher=The Vitra Museum|date=1982}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Collections: Gaetano Pesce|url=http://www.philamuseum.org|publisher=Philadelphia Museum of Art}}</ref><ref name=Reddot>{{cite web |url=http://en.red-dot.org/1694.html |title=Gaetano Pesce is AW Ontwerper van het Jaar |accessdate=2007-03-27 |author=reddot online |date=2006-02-07 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Gaetano Pesce Italian 1939, La Spezia, Italy|url=https://www.sfmoma.org/artist/Gaetano_Pesce|website=www.sfmoma.org}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Gaetano Pesc|url=https://collection.cooperhewitt.org/people/18044441/|website=collection.cooperhewitt.org}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Gaetano Pesce: Architecture, Design, Art|date=1989|publisher=Rizzoli International Publications|location=United States of America|isbn=0847810860|edition=1st}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=The Collection: Gaetano Pesce|url=http://www.moma.org|website=MoMA|publisher=The Museum of Modern Art}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Aa.Vv.|title=100 objects of italian design La Triennale di Milano: Permanent Collection of Italian Design, The Milan Triennale|date=2012|publisher=Gangemi Editore|isbn=9788849247060}}</ref>
=== Architecture Projects, selected === * 1980: ''Late Entries to the [[Chicago Tribune]] Tower Competition, II.'' <ref>{{cite news|last1=Didero|first1=Maria Cristina|title=The value of imperfection|url=http://www.domusweb.it|publisher=Domus|date=August 28, 2014}}</ref> * 1983: ''Project for rehabilitation of the ''Lingotto, Turin, Italy,''for the Fiat group * 1984: ''la Maison des enfants au [[Parc de la Villette]], [[Paris]], France <ref>{{cite book|author1=Barzilay, Marianne|author2=Lombard - Valentino, Lucette|author3=Hayward, Catherine|title=L'Invention Du Parc : Parc De La Villette, Paris, Concours International; Parc De La Villette, Paris [International competition, 1982 - 1983]|date=1984|publisher=Graphite / E.P.P.V.|location=Paris}}</ref> * 1986: ''Hubin Apartment, '' [[Paris]] <ref>{{cite book|last1=Hayat|first1=Yves J|title=Gaetano Pesce : la maison Hubin|date=1993|publisher=Galerie Catherine et Stéphane de Beyrie|location=Paris}}</ref> * 1991: ''[[TBWA\Chiat\Day]] Offices,'' New York <ref>{{cite news|last1=Lieber|first1=Ronald B.|title=Cool Offices Blowing Out Your Walls and Gettng Rid of Private Offices Is A Great Way To Eencourge Teamwork; Just Be Sure to Respect People's Need for Peace and Quiet|url=http://archive.fortune.com|archive-url=https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20140712160702/http://fortune.com/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2014-07-12|publisher=Fortune Magazine|date=December 9, 1996|access-date=2018-01-24|df=}}</ref> * 1993: ''Organic Building,'' Osaka, [[Japan]] <ref>{{cite news|title=Gaetano Pesce retrospective opens in NYC|url=http://archinect.com|publisher=Archinet News|date=May 2013}}</ref> * 1994: ''Shuman Residence'', New York <ref>{{cite news|last1=Ballen|first1=Sian|last2=Hauge|first2=Lesley|title=Ruth Shuman|url=http://www.newyorksocialdiary.com|publisher=New York Social Diary|date=November 9, 2012}}</ref> * 1994: ''Art Gallery.'' Knokke-le-Zoute, Belgium * 1994: ''Bahia House, [[Brazil]]'' <ref>{{cite news|last1=Sutherland|first1=Jim|title=20 Odd Questions: Gaetano Pesce|url=https://www.wsj.com|publisher=The Wall Street Journal|date=March 22, 2013}}</ref>
[[File:" 09 - ITALY - TDM - Red armchair - Serie UP (UP5 and UP6) Gaetano Pesce chairs and B&B Italia at Triennale Design Museum.jpg|thumb|" 09 - ITALY - TDM - Red armchair - Serie UP (UP5 and UP6) Gaetano Pesce chairs and B&B Italia at Triennale Design Museum]]
== Industrial Design == Since the 1960s, Mr. Pesce has researched the function and form of utilitarian and decorative objects, including furniture, jewelry, and shoes, from the perspective of human emotion, environment, and production. Mr. Pesce is known for innovative high-minded modern design with wit and style.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/title/creativitalia-the-joy-of-italian-design/oclc/26402623&referer=brief_results|title=Creativitalia: the joy of Italian design|last=Pesce|first=Gaetano|last2=Celant|first2=Germano|date=1990|publisher=Electa ; Hatsubaimoto Kureativitaria Jikkō Iinkai|location=Milano; Tōkyō|language=English}}</ref> Mr. Pesce has challenged accepted standards of abstraction, uniformity, and homogeneity. On the architect designer, critic Susan Slesin wrote, "For Gaetano Pesce, to be modern is to face the world squarely and use design as a means to comment on it.<ref name="The New York Times">{{cite news|last1=Slesin|first1=Suzanne|title=Modern Notions Of Design: The Furniture of Gaetano Pesce|url=https://www.nytimes.com|publisher=The New York Times|date=November 10, 1988}}</ref> Mr. Pesce has expanded the established notions of [[Modernism]] through the creation functional, imperfect, and warm [[product design]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Sutherland|first1=Jim|title=Gaetano Pesce: the provocative Italian architect and designer on his history of doing things 'badly'-on purpose, of course|publisher=The Wall Street Journal|date=March 23, 2013}}</ref> He connects art and society to design through organic form, for production by [[B&B Italia]] (formerly C & B Italia),<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/title/long-life-of-design-in-italy-b-b-italia-50-years-and-beyond/oclc/990773592&referer=brief_results|title=The long life of design in Italy: B & B Italia 50 years and beyond|last=Casciani|first=Stefano|date=2016|publisher=Skira Editore|isbn=9788857231808|location=Milano|language=English}}</ref> [[Vitra (furniture)|Vitra]], [[Cassina S.p.A.|Cassina]], and fabric design, such as ''People'' (1987), composed of 570 different figures, all of which incorporate ideas about variation and diversity in contemporary society.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/title/process-50-product-designs-from-concept-to-manufacture/oclc/191856123&referer=brief_results|title=Process: 50 product designs from concept to manufacture|last=Hudson|first=Jennifer|date=2008|publisher=Laurence King|isbn=9781856695411|location=London|language=English}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/title/textiles-and-new-technology-2010/oclc/929911867&referer=brief_results|title=Textiles and new Technology 2010|last=Braddock|first=Sarah|last2=O'Mahony|first2=Marie|date=1994|publisher=Artemis|isbn=1874056080|location=London|language=English}}</ref>
Pesce's iconic feminist armchair - a fulsome bulbous form and attached ball-shaped ottoman - alternately referred to as La Mamma, Big Mama, Donna, and Up chair - continues to inspire interpretation nearly 50 years after its creation.<ref>https://www.architecturaldigest.com/story/the-story-behind-gaetano-pesces-iconic-armchair</ref> According to curator and author of SuperDesign, Maria Cristina Didero, "Pesce wanted to produce something about the condition of women in the world. The chair can be read as the mother, and the stool her child. But it could also be a ball and chain [suggesting] woman and the prison she was obliged to live in."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/art-and-design/melbourne-design-week-celebrates-a-feverish-period-for-italys-radicals-20180223-h0wjfz.html|title=Melbourne Design Week celebrates a feverish period for Italy's radicals|last=Edgar|first=Ray|date=2018-02-26|website=The Sydney Morning Herald|language=en|access-date=2018-05-29}}</ref>
Mr. Pesce is perhaps best known for his work with resin, molds, and casting techniques used to create objects, including vases, chairs, lamps and the two-dimensional reliefs that the designer calls “industrial skins.”<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/title/furniture-machine-furniture-since-1990/oclc/70672622&referer=brief_results|title=The furniture machine: furniture since 1990|last=Williams|first=Gareth|date=2006|publisher=V & A|isbn=9781851774944|location=London|language=English}}</ref> Since 1987, he has infused ordinary materials with experimental additives, such as liquid plant resin, and worked with foam and urethane, simplify the manufacturing processes and adapt limited industrial capabilities.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wmagazine.com/story/the-legendary-designer-gaetano-pesce-wrings-feminism-out-of-furniture|title=The Legendary Designer Gaetano Pesce Wrings Feminism Out of Furniture|last=Viladas|first=Pilar|work=W Magazine|access-date=2018-05-29|language=en}}</ref> Pesce credits the early influence of his student work with three venerable Murano glassmakers<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/title/yalos-why-glass/oclc/226976604&referer=brief_results|title=Yalos: why glass?|last=Barbero|first=Luca Massimo|last2=Claudia Gian Ferrari studio di consulenza per il '900 italiano (Milan|first2=Italy)|last3=Caterina Tognon Arte Contemporanea (Venice|first3=Italy)|date=2008|publisher=Charta|isbn=9788881586691|location=Milan; New York}}</ref> — Moretti, Vistosi, and Venini — whose casting techniques for informing his label-defying works of sculpture, furniture, vessels and paintings.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/moca-pacific-design-center-honors-926785|title=MOCA Pacific Design Center Honors "Disruptor" Artist Gaetano Pesce|work=The Hollywood Reporter|access-date=2018-05-29|language=en}}</ref> Even Pesce's own experimentation in glassmaking has led to inventive techniques and highly original results.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.designboom.com/design/gaetano-pesce-five-glassmaking-techniques-murano-glass-museum-06-02-2017/|title=gaetano pesce's five glassmaking techniques at murano glass museum|date=2017-06-02|work=designboom {{!}} architecture & design magazine|access-date=2018-05-29|language=en-US}}</ref> Mr. Pesce has even used urethane resin to create necklaces, bracelets, brooches, and rings.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.architecturaldigest.com/story/gaetano-pesce-jewelry-collection|title=Gaetano Pesce unveils a new line of jewelry {{!}} Architectural Digest|work=Architectural Digest|access-date=2018-05-29|language=en}}</ref>
For Mr. Pesce, the design and development of portable goods have always incorporated craft-specialization, history, humor, and the human need for connection. Mr. Pesce's [[industrial design]] techniques such as ''diversified series production'' is a process by which he experiments with materials using a craft manufacturing sensibility applied to mass production methodology.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Viladas|first1=Pilar|title=What's the Big Idea?|url=https://www.nytimes.com|publisher=The New York Times|date=June 23, 2002}}</ref> On the production line, for example, factory workers vary proportions to produce a series of objects with a "one of a kind" quality.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Giovannini|first1=Joseph|title=Gaetano Pesce: ‘One-of-a-Kind Iconic Works, 1967-2015|url=https://www.nytimes.com|publisher=NY Times Art & Design|date=March 26, 2015}}</ref>
Socio-political messaging is found in Mr. Pesce's collections, such as "Nobody’s Perfect" (2002) by Zerodisegno, and the 2010 series of irregularly shaped tables for [[Cassina S.p.A.|Cassina]], which together form the recognizable shape of a boot shape, commemorating the 150th anniversary of the Unification of [[Italy]],<ref name="The New York Times"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Sensantunna|url=http://sessantuna.cassina.com|publisher=Cassina}}</ref> and celebrate human diversity and connection,<ref>https://www.theartnewspaper.com/news/object-lessons-a-psychedelic-cabinet-from-gaetano-pesce-and-more</ref> as well as one-of-a-kind pieces like “America Table” (2012), with a red-white-and-blue resin tabletop American flag supported on letters that spell “independence,” and “Verbal Abuse” (1994), a tall, grided lamp that bends forward with attachable weights.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/title/millers-20th-century-design-the-definitive-illustrated-sourcebook/oclc/812809113&referer=brief_results|title=Miller's 20th century design: the definitive illustrated sourcebook.|last=Miller|first=Judith|date=2012|publisher=Mitchell beazley|isbn=9781845337230|location=London|language=English}}</ref>
Mr. Pesce's unconventional mixed-media industrial design and organic forms collected in major museums across the world ascribe the work to the realm of art. A 2014 retrospective exhibition ''The Time of Diversity'' at the [[MAXXI]], National Museum of the 21st Century Arts, [[Rome]], charted the artfulness of Pesce's product design from the 1960s to the present.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Manuelli|first1=Sara|title=Design maverick Gaetano Pesce explores diversity in a retrospective at the Maxxi Museum, Rome|url=http://www.wallpaper.com/|date=July 24, 2014}}</ref> Recent exhibitions such as “What it is to be Human,” at The Peninsula Chicago, Art Basel in Hong Kong, and an artist-in-resident program at Peninsula Beijing, all featuring works by Gaetano Pesce that expand the renown artist and architect's history of public commitment to the arts.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://michiganavemag.com/sponsored-the-peninsula-showcases-gaetano-pesce|title=Sponsored: The Peninsula Chicago Showcases Gaetano Pesce|access-date=2018-05-29|language=en}}</ref> In 2016, Pesce unveiled a site-specific sculpture "Majesty Betrayed" in [[Piazza Santa Maria Novella]]. The monumental female figure wrapped in a long cloak by Pesce was inspired by the Christian Maestà iconography of the Madonna on the Throne - the highly venerated Madonna Rucellai by Duccio di Boninsegna (1285), in [[Santa Maria Novella]] and later moved in the twentieth century the [[Uffizi]].<ref>http://www.theflorentine.net/art-culture/2016/11/majesty-betrayed-gaetano-pesce/</ref> Pesce's sculpture entitled "Porta Ritratti" (2018) for the Milan Fuorisalone was exhibited at the entrance of the [[Brera Academy]] of Fine Arts, and later, the 13th edition of Design Miami / Basel. The ambitious installation - a chair measuring over 13-feet (4-meters) high representing 20 human faces - according to Pesce, " is a Trojan horse that penetrates the Rocca dell'Arte making victims among the old mentality." The work is another compelling tribute to cultural diversity within society.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://design.pambianconews.com/gaetano-pesce-ad-art-basel-con-la-sedia-porta-ritratti/|title=Gaetano Pesce ad Art Basel con la ‘Sedia Porta Ritratti’ {{!}} Pambianco Design|website=design.pambianconews.com|language=it-IT|access-date=2018-05-29}}</ref>
== Gallery and museum exhibitions == Mr. Pesce's architecture and design has been published, exhibited, and collected internationally and included in the permanent collections of museums around the world.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/title/gaetano-pesce-murano-cinque-tecniche-per-il-vetro/oclc/989139543&referer=brief_results|title=Gaetano Pesce: Murano : cinque tecniche per il vetro|last=Pesce|first=Gaetano|last2=Corda|first2=Sara|date=2017|publisher=C. Grenzi|isbn=9788884316653|location=Foggia|language=Italian}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/title/italian-design/oclc/216939341&referer=brief_results|title=Italian design|last=Bosoni|first=Giampiero|last2=Museum of Modern Art (New York|first2=N.Y.)|date=2008|publisher=MoMA ; 5 Continents Editions ; Distributed in the United States and Canada by D.A.P./Distributed Art Publishers|isbn=9780870707384|location=New York; Milan; New York|language=English}}</ref>
=== Solo Exhibitions === * 1975: ''Gaetano Pesce, Le futur est peut-être passé = Gaetano Pesce, The future is perhaps past : Centre de Création Industrielle, Etablissement Public du Centre Beaubourg, Musée des Arts Décoratifs, Paris <ref>{{Cite book|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.5479/sil.386901.39088006374375|title=Guide sommaire a travers le Musée des arts décoratifs|date=1905|publisher=Lahure}}</ref> * 1983: ''Gaetano Pesce : a [[Yale School of Architecture]] Exhibition.''<ref>{{cite news|last1=Martin|first1=Douglas|title=Spring In La Cite|url=https://www.nytimes.com|publisher=The New York Times: Travel|date=April 22, 1984}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Gaetano Pesce : a Yale School of Architecture Exhibition, October 31-December 2, 1983|date=1983|publisher=New Haven, Conn. : Yale School of Architecture}}</ref> * 1986: ''Gaetano Pesce 1975-1985. [[Strasbourg Museum of Modern and Contemporary Art]], France.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Pesce, Gaetano|title=Gaetano Pesce, 1975-1985: Musée d'art moderne de Strasbourg, 29 mai-17 août 1986.|date=1986|publisher=Le Musée|location=Strasbourg|oclc=192378148}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Prina|first=Daniela|title=Pesce, Gaetano (1939–)|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.5040/9781472596154-bed-p035|journal=The Bloomsbury Encyclopedia of Design|doi=10.5040/9781472596154-bed-p035}}</ref> * 1988: ''Gaetano Pesce: Drawings, Models, Prototypes.'' [[Max Protetch]] Gallery, New York <ref>{{cite news|last1=Slesin|first1=Suzanne|title=Modern Notions Of Design: The Furniture of Gaetano Pesce|url=https://www.nytimes.com|publisher=The New York Times: Home & Garden|date=November 10, 1988}}</ref> * 1988: ''Modern Times Again.'' == Academic experience == For 28 years, Mr. Pesce taught architectural design at the [[Institut National des Sciences Appliquées]] (INSA) (National Institute of Applied Sciences), [[Strasbourg, France]]; [[Domus Academy]], [[Milan, Italy]]; [[City University of Hong Kong]], [[China]]; Escola da Cidade, (AEAUSP), (Architectural School of São Paulo), [[Brazil]]; [[Carnegie Mellon]], [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]]; [[Ohio State University]], [[Columbus, Ohio]]; and in [[New York City|New York]], since 1980, at the [[Cooper Union]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Vanlaethem|first1=France|title=Architecture, design, art|date=1989|publisher=Rizzoli|location=New York|isbn=0847810860|edition=1. publ. in the United States of America.}}</ref>

[[File:Gakushuin in 1933.JPG|right|thumb|Gakushūin in 1933]]
[[File:Gakushuin Logo.gif|thumb|Gakushuin Crest and Logo]]
The {{nihongo|'''Gakushūin'''|学習院}} or '''Peers School''' ('''Gakushūin School Corporation'''), also known as '''Gakushūjo''', is a [[Japan]]ese educational institution in [[Tokyo]], originally established to educate the children of Japan's nobility.<ref name="nussbaum230">[[Louis-Frédéric|Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric]]. (2002). [https://books.google.com/books?id=p2QnPijAEmEC&pg=PA230#v=onepage&q&f=false "Gakushū-in"] in Japan Encyclopedia, p. 230.</ref> Gakushuin is composed of the Kindergarten, Elementary School, Middle School, High School, and University.
==History== The Peers' School was founded in 1847 by [[Emperor Ninkō]] in [[Kyoto]].<ref name="gwc">[http://www.gwc.gakushuin.ac.jp/english/history.html "History of Gakushuin" at Gakushuin Women's College]; retrieved 2013-2-27.</ref> Its purpose was to educate the children of the Imperial aristocracy (''[[kuge]]'').<ref>[[Richard Ponsonby-Fane|Ponsonby-Fane, Richard]]. (1915). ''The Imperial Family of Japan,'' p. 26.</ref> Prior to the disestablishment of the Peerage in 1947, commoners had restricted access to Gakushuin, with limited slots only to the Elementary School and Middle School. In 1947, with the US mandated disestablishment of the Kazoku system, enrollment in Gakushuin was fully opened up to the general public. The Administration of the School was transferred to the [[Ministry_of_Education,_Culture,_Sports,_Science_and_Technology|Ministry of Education]] at this time. Previous to 1947, Gakushuin was administered by the [[Imperial Household Agency]].
===Precepts=== Emperor Ninko had four [[Maxim (philosophy)|maxim]]s inscribed on the walls of the ''Gakushūin'' building,<ref name="brinkley664">Brinkley, Frank. (1915). [https://books.google.com/books?id=NnsEAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA664&dq= ''A History of the Japanese People,'' p. 664].</ref> including # Walk in the paths trodden by the feet of the great sages.<ref name="brinkley664"/> # Revere the righteous canons of the empire.<ref name="brinkley664"/> # He that has not learned the sacred doctrines, how can he govern himself?<ref name="brinkley664"/> # He that is ignorant of the classics, how can he regulate his own conduct?<ref name="brinkley664"/>
The school was moved to Tokyo in 1877.<ref name="nussbaum230"/> Its new purpose was to educate the children of the [[kazoku|modern aristocracy]]. Members of the Imperial Family continue to study at Gakushūin.
===Timeline=== * '''1847''': founded as Peers' School<ref name="nussbaum230"/> * '''1877''': the school was established in [[Tokyo]]<ref name="nussbaum230"/> * '''1884''': ''Gakushūin'' became an Imperial institution.<ref name="nussbaum230"/> * '''1885''': Peeresses' School was created<ref name="gwc"/> * '''1947''': ''Gakushūin'' became a private institution.<ref name="nussbaum230"/>
==Presidents== {|class="wikitable" style="font-size: 95%;" |- !No.!!Name!!Year!!Title!!Military rank!!Note |- ! 1 | [[Tachibana Taneyuki]] | 1877–1884 | [[Viscount]] |align="center"| – | Last lord of [[Miike Domain]]. |- ! 2 | [[Tani Tateki]] | 1884–1885 | [[Viscount]] | [[Lieutenant General]] ([[Imperial Japanese Army|IJA]]) | Former president of [[Imperial Japanese Army Academy]] |- ! 3 | [[Ōtori Keisuke]] | 1885–1887 | [[Baron]] |align="center"| – | Member of [[Privy Council (Japan)|Privy council]]. |- ! 4 | [[Miura Gorō]] | 1887–1891 | [[Viscount]] | [[Lieutenant General]] ([[Imperial Japanese Army|IJA]]) | |- ! 5 | [[Iwakura Tomosada]] | 1891 | [[Duke]] |align="center"| – | |- ! 6 | [[Tanaka Mitsuaki]] | 1891–1894 | [[Viscount]] | [[Major General]] ([[Imperial Japanese Army|IJA]]) | |- ! 7 | [[Konoe Atsumaro]] | 1894–1903 | [[Duke]] |align="center"| – | The heir of [[Konoe family]]. The president of [[House of Peers (Japan)|House of Peers]] (1892–1905) |- ! 8 | [[Kikuchi Dairoku]] | 1903–1904 | [[Baron]] |align="center"| – | Mathematician and [[Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology (Japan)|Minister of Education]] (1901–1903). |- ! 9 | [[Yamaguchi Einosuke]] | 1905–1906 |align="center"| – |align="center"| – | Physicist. |- ! 10 | [[Nogi Maresuke]] | 1906–1912 | [[Count]] | [[General]] ([[Imperial Japanese Army|IJA]]) |rowspan="2"| [[Emperor Showa]] entered school in 1908 and graduated in 1914. |- ! 11 | [[Ōsako Naoharu]] | 1912–1917 | [[Viscount]] | [[General]] ([[Imperial Japanese Army|IJA]]) |- ! 12 | [[Hōjō Tokiyuki (Scouting)|Hōjō Tokiyuki]] | 1917–1920 |align="center"| – |align="center"| – | Mathematician. Former president of [[Tohoku University|Tohoku Imperial University]] (1913–1917). |- ! 13 | [[Ichinohe Hyoe]] | 1920–1922 |align="center"| – | [[General]] ([[Imperial Japanese Army|IJA]]) | The [[Inspectorate General of Military Training]] |- ! 14 | [[Fukuhara Ryojirō]] | 1922–1929 |align="center"| – |align="center"| – | Former president of [[Tohoku University|Tohoku Imperial University]] (1917–1919) |- ! 15 | [[Araki Torasaburō]] | 1929–1937 |align="center"| – |align="center"| – | Medical scientist. Former president of [[Kyoto University|Kyoto Imperial University]] (1915–1929) |- ! 16 | [[Kichisaburō Nomura|Nomura Kichisaburō]] | 1937–1939 |align="center"| – | [[Admiral]] ([[Imperial Japanese Navy|IJN]]) | |- ! 17 | [[Yamanashi Katsunoshin]] | 1939–1946 |align="center"| – | [[Admiral]] ([[Imperial Japanese Navy|IJN]]) | |}

revision.comment: /* Higher School Certificate Professional Qualification (HSC Pro) */
revision.text:
The '''Higher School Certificate''' is an academic qualification in [[Mauritius]] awarded upon the completion of Upper 6 Form, the final stage of [[Secondary education|secondary school]]. The qualification is awarded upon earning passing marks on the [[A-level]] exams administered by the [[Mauritius Examinations Syndicate]], in conjunction with the [[University of Cambridge]] Local Examinations Syndicate of the [[Cambridge International Examinations]] board.
==Editions==
===Higher School Certificate (HSC)=== The traditional Higher School Certificate (HSC) is the main school-leaving qualification awarded by Mauritian [[Secondary education in Mauritius|secondary schools]]. Requirements include A Levels and AS Levels in subjects chosen by the student.
Successful students may receive academic recognition and are eligible to compete for laureateship, a scholarship scheme offered by the Mauritian [[Government of Mauritius|government]] for students pursuing [[Higher education in Mauritius|higher education]].
===Higher School Certificate Professional Qualification (HSC Pro)=== The Higher School Certificate Professional Qualification (HSC Pro) is an alternative school-leaving qualification with a modified curriculum and structure, which allows students to pursue both an academic curriculum and [[Vocational education in Mauritius|vocational]] training, to be prepared for [[Higher education in Mauritius|tertiary studies]] as well as employment.<ref name="HSCProInf">{{cite web |url=http://www.gov.mu/portal/sites/mesweb/sc_hsc_Section/2013/hsc_professional/2013_hsc_professional_inf_booklet.pdf |title=HSC Professional}}</ref> The qualification will be introduced as a pilot in 2015.<ref name="HSCProInf" />
There are certain unique features of this qualification that distinguish it from the traditional Higher School Certificate.<ref name="HSCProInf" /> One is the inclusion of the [[Cambridge Technicals|Cambridge International Technical]] in [[Information and communications technology|ICT]], adapted to the local context, in place of an A Level.<ref name="HSCProInf" /> Another is replacement of the AS General Paper with a mandatory alternative, the AS Global Perspectives, which is designed to develop communication, analytical and research skills. <ref name="HSCProInf" /> Another is the Work Placement Component (WPC), a structured and supervised placement that provides practical work experience in the industry.<ref name="HSCProInf" />
The structure for the qualification includes:<ref name="HSCProInf" /> *2 or 3 A Levels, including the Cambridge International Technical in ICT *2 or 3 AS Levels, including the AS Alternative to the General Paper *The Work Placement Component (WPC)
The alternative qualification is recognised by local and overseas universities, enabling students who successfully complete the qualification to seek admission in universities.<ref name="HSCProInf" /> HSC Pro students may not compete for laureateship, as can traditional HSC students, but may participate in alternative schemes provided by the Mauritian [[Government of Mauritius|government]] for further studies as well as employment.<ref name="HSCProInf" />
==Subjects== Typically 3 to 5 primary subjects are chosen to study at AS-level, and at least 3 subjects are further studied to A2-level. Both the AS (Advanced Subsidiary) and A2 years must be completed for the full A-level qualification to be completed; an AS-level qualification may also be awarded after the first year.
===AS-level=== Cambridge Higher School Certificate candidates may take the following subjects at AS-level:<ref name="MruHSCStats">{{cite web |url=http://www.gov.mu/portal/sites/mesweb/hsc_stats.htm |title=STATISTICS: HIGHER SCHOOL CERTIFICATE}}</ref>
*General Paper *Divinity *Islamic Studies *Hinduism *French Language *Environmental Management *Hindi Literature *Arabic Language *Chinese Language *German Language *Spanish Language *Urdu Language *Hindi Language *Tamil Language *Telugu Language *English Language *Language and Literature in English *Law *Art and Design *Travel and Tourism *Physical Education *Computer Science *Marine Science *Thinking Skills *Literature in English *Geography *History *Sociology *Biology *Design and Technology *Accounting *Business Studies *Economics *Mathematics
===A-level=== Cambridge Higher School Certificate candidates may take the following subjects at A2-level:<ref name="MruHSCStats">{{cite web |url=http://www.gov.mu/portal/sites/mesweb/hsc_stats.htm |title=STATISTICS: HIGHER SCHOOL CERTIFICATE}}</ref>
*Divinity *Islamic Studies *Hinduism *Law *French (Mauritius) *Food Studies *Art and Design *Travel and Tourism *Physical Education *Design and Textiles *Urdu *Arabic *Hindi *Marathi *Tamil *Telugu *Computing *Marine Science *Thinking Skills *Literature in English *Geography *History *Psychology *Sociology *Biology *Chemistry *Physics *Music *Design and Technology *Accounting *Business Studies *Economics *Mathematics *Chinese *German *Spanish *computer Science
===HSC Pro=== Higher School Certificate Professional Qualification (HSC Pro) students additionally take the following subjects:<ref name="HSCProInf" /> *Cambridge International Technical in ICT *AS Global Perspectives
==Progression== Students who successfully earn the Higher School Certificate may then progress onto [[Tertiary education|tertiary]] study. Students who are unsuccessful in obtaining the qualification may then transition from the academic stream to the vocational stream and progress onto [[Vocational_education_in_Mauritius#Vocational_qualifications|vocational]] programmes of study. Students may also choose to obtain [[GCE Advanced Level|A Level]] qualifications at a later time.
==See also== * [[Education in Mauritius]] * [[Form III Certificate]] * [[Certificate of Primary Education]] * [[School Certificate (Mauritius)]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Education in Mauritius}}
[[Category:Education in Mauritius]] [[Category:Graduation]] [[Category:Secondary school qualifications]]

The '''Independent Education System''' of Israel ({{lang-he| החינוך העצמאי}} - which is translated "independent education" and could be transliterated as ''Khinukh Atsmai'' or ''Chinuch Atzmai'') is an alternate school system run by and serving the needs of the [[Haredi Judaism|Haredi]] (ultra-Orthodox Jewish) community of [[Israel]]. It was established in 1953 by a decision of the [[Moetzes Gedolei HaTorah]] ([[Council of Torah Sages]] of [[Agudath Yisrael]] in [[Israel]]) and implemented through the ''State Education law''. It was initially led by Rabbi [[Zalman Sorotzkin]] and is run by an umbrella center that operates numerous schools throughout the country.
The diverse nature of Israel’s society is accommodated within the framework of the [[Education in Israel|Israeli education systems]]. Different sectors of the population attend different schools. Although parents are comforted by the fact that their children’s school may more or less reflect their basic worldview, this separation results in very little contact among the various segments of Israeli society. Schools are divided into five groups: State schools (''mamlachti''), attended by the majority of the pupils; State religious schools (''[[mamlachti dati]]''), which emphasize Jewish studies, tradition and observance; Independent religious schools (''Chinuch Atzmai'') which focus almost entirely on Talmud Torah and offer very little in terms of secular subjects; Private schools which reflect the philosophies of specific groups of parents (Democratic Schools) or are based on a curriculum of a foreign country (e.g. The American School); and lastly, Arab schools, with instruction in Arabic and a focus on Arab history, religions and culture.
There are approximately 80,000 students currently enrolled in Chinuch Atzmai schools, which include [[Beis Yaakov]] schools for girls, [[Talmud Torah]], [[Cheder]] and [[Yeshiva Ketana]] for boys. There is a strong emphasis on Jewish studies in these programs.
The schools are partially supported by the State; however, the Ministry of Education is not responsible for the hiring and firing of teachers or for the registration of pupils. Schools in the Chinuch Atzmai system are allocated 55% of the budget that regular state schools receive and are required to teach 55% of the Ministry of Education's curriculum. Chinuch Atzmai's funding has traditionally been supplemented by donations from outside Israel, particularly the United States. Rabbi [[Aharon Kotler]], one of the movement's founders, was extremely instrumental in fundraising for the organization. Due to sharp cuts in state funding over recent years, the movement has had to redouble its efforts in order to keep schools from closing.
The center was a main focus of the controversial [[Immanuel Beit Yaakov controversy|Court ruling]] against the [[Beit Yaakov]] school in [[Immanuel (town)#Controversy|Immanuel]] in summer 2010, when it was fined for not complying with the court's ruling.<ref>http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3655796,00.html</ref>
==External links and references== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20120325133320/http://www.5tjt.com/local-news/10530-chinuch-atzmai-torah-schools-for-israel Chinuch Atzmai: Torah Schools For Israel], 5 Towns Jewish Times: 5TJT Staff, May 2011
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Education in Israel]] [[Category:Orthodox Jewish educational institutions]] [[Category:Haredi Judaism in Israel]] [[Category:1953 establishments in Israel]]

{{Infobox Union |name = Intern Aware |country = [[England]] |members = |full_name = Intern Aware |image = |founded = 2010 |current = |office = |people = Gus Baker (Co-Director)
Ben Lyons(Co-Director) |website = [http://www.internaware.org/ www.internaware.org] |head = |dissolved_date = |dissolved_state = |merged_into = }} '''Intern Aware''' is the United Kingdom national campaign for fair [[internship]]s, founded in 2010. Working closely in cooperation with businesses, trade bodies and trade unions, they aim to help employers develop high quality internship schemes with recruitment based on merit, and payment that complies with [[employment law]]. They also work with interns to ensure they receive the pay they are potentially entitled to by law. They believe that unpaid internships are exploitative, exclusive and unfair. By asking people to work without pay, employers exclude those with talent, ambition and drive who cannot afford to work for free. They campaign that employers and young people alike benefit from the best graduates getting the best jobs. They argue that paying interns a fair wage can ensure that this happens. == Policies == Much of Intern Aware’s argument focuses on how interns fit into the [[National Minimum Wage Act 1998]]. '''Main proposal''' • (Excluding existing exemptions) the [[UK Government]] should designate anyone who has undertaken a period of work experience for over four weeks to be a “[[worker]]” under the meaning of the National Minimum Wage (NMW) Act. '''Other proposals''' *“Naming and shaming” of persistent, high profile offenders who break the NMW Act; *Third parties should be able to complain about non-enforcement of the NMW; *Advertisements for illegal work should be monitored; *Better support and guidance to vulnerable workers; *Raise penalties for non-payment of the NMW *A new paid internship scheme for the [[Voluntary sector|third sector]]. == History == The organisation started as a [[Facebook]] group named "Interns Must Be Paid The Minimum Wage". {{cite journal |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1977130,00.html |title=Working for Free: The Boom in Adult Interns |first=Eve|last=Tahmincioglu |date=12 April 2010 |journal=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]}} It has led campaigns focused on the non-payment of [[Parliament of the United Kingdom|parliamentary]] interns. {{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/mps-should-pay-us-as-employees-say-parliaments-revolting-interns-2078449.html |title=MPs should pay us as employees, say Parliament's revolting interns |work=[[The Independent]] |first1=Tom|last1=Rowley |first2=Michael|last2=Savage |date=14 September 2010}} {{cite web |url=http://www.leftfootforward.org/2011/03/british-democracy-is-run-on-unpaid-labour/ |title=British democracy is run on unpaid labour |work=Left Foot Forward |date=30 March 2011}} {{cite journal |url=http://www.newstatesman.com/society/2010/02/minimum-wage-interns-mps |title=House of poshos |first=Rowenna|last=Davis |journal=[[New Statesman]] |date=18 February 2010}} It also campaigned during the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]]'s leadership election, securing the support of all five candidates {{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2010/jul/08/support-tories-steep-price-internship?INTCMP=SRCH |title=Support the Tories? That's a steep price for an internship |first=Zoe|last=Williams |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=8 July 2010}} {{cite web |url=http://waugh.standard.co.uk/2010/07/andy-burnham-unpaid-volunteers-and-interns.html |first=Paul|last=Waugh |work=[[Evening Standard|The London Evening Standard]] |title=Andy Burnham, unpaid 'volunteers' and 'interns' |date=21 July 2010}} and persuading [[Andy Burnham]] MP to demand that the [[BBC]] end [[unpaid work]] experience. {{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/bbc/7904849/Andy-Burnham-BBC-should-end-unpaid-work-experience.html |title=Andy Burnham: BBC should end unpaid work experience |first=Neil|last=Midgley |work=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]] |date=23 July 2010}} The campaign has also drawn attention to the connection between increased graduate unemployment and unpaid interns. {{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2010/sep/21/internships-increasing-graduates-public-sector?INTCMP=SRCH |title=The 1994 Group of universities advertises for graduate volunteers |first=Janet|last=Murray |date=21 September 2010 |work=The Guardian}} {{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/education/education-news/the-lost-generation-out-of-work-out-of-luck--graduates-finding-it-tough-2023991.html |title=The lost generation: Out of work, out of luck - graduates finding it tough |first1=Lindsey|last1=Fineran |first2=James|last2=Burtun |work=The Independent |date=11 July 2010}} {{Cite episode | title= 12 April 2010 | episodelink = | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00rw8n2 | accessdate = | series = Woman's Hour | serieslink = Woman's Hour | credits = | network = [[BBC Radio 4]] | airdate = 12 April 2010 }} == References == {{reflist}} [[Category:Internships]]

revision.comment: added [[Category:Latter Day Saints from Utah]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
'''Jeffry H. Larson''', Ph.D., LMFT, CFLE, is a Professor of Marriage and [[family therapy|Family Therapy]] at [[Brigham Young University]]. He is the author of ''Should We Stay Together? A Scientifically Proven Method for Evaluating Your Relationship and Improving its Chances for Long Term Success'' (San Francisco: Jossey-Bass, 2000) and the [[E-book]] entitled ''The Great Marriage Tune-Up Book: A Proven Program for Evaluating and Renewing Your Relationship'' (March 2004), among others.
He obtained his B.S. and M.S. degrees in Psychology from BYU and a Ph.D. in Marriage and Family Therapy from [[Texas Tech University]]. He is a licensed marriage and family therapist, and the former chair of the Utah State MFT Licensing Board. He is the former chairperson and professor of the Marriage and Family graduate program at BYU.<ref>[http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=NewsLibrary&p_multi=DSNB&d_place=DSNB&p_theme=newslibrary2&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0F36496073B4B01D&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM Deseret News, The (Salt Lake City, UT) - December 16, 1997 ]</ref> He is the author of over 70 scholarly journal articles and book chapters. He was awarded the Distinguished Alumnus Award by Texas Tech University in 2001.
Prior to joining the BYU faculty Larson was on the faculty of [[Montana State University]].<ref>[http://www.lds.org/ensign/1987/02/how-to-unite-a-step-family?lang=eng ''Ensign'' Feb. 1987]</ref>
==Personal life== Dr. Larson was married in 1972 to the former Dianna Jean Spear and is the father of 4 children, Geoffrey Larson, Dillon Larson, Tyler Larson (his favorite) and Hallie Larson. Larson is a Latter-day Saint.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070323042235/http://www.findarticles.com/p/search?tb=art&qt=%22Larson%2C%20Jeffry%20H%22 A list of articles by Larson]
{{Authority control}}

revision.comment: removed [[Category:20th-century Swedish opera singers]]; added [[Category:20th-century Swedish singers]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
[[File:Forsell, John - porträtt med signatur - AF.jpg|thumb|John Forsell pictured in a photograph signed with a personal dedication.]]
'''Carl Johan Jacob Forsell''' (6 November 1868 – 30 May 1941), known as '''John Forsell''', was a prominent Swedish [[baritone]], opera administrator and teacher of voice. He was the leading baritone of the [[Royal Swedish Opera]] (RSO) from 1896–1918, and thereafter sang roles periodically with the company until his last stage performance in 1938. From 1923-1939 he served as the director of the RSO. He also sang leading roles as a guest artist with opera companies internationally, drawing particular acclaim for his portrayal of the title character in [[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart]]'s ''[[Don Giovanni]]''.
In 1899, Forsell was awarded the [[Litteris et Artibus]] and, a decade later, he was named a [[Hovsångare]]. The [[Royal Swedish Academy of Music]] awarded him membership in 1906.<ref>Rosenthal, H. and Warrack, J. (1979), "Forsell, John", ''The Concise Oxford Dictionary of Opera'', 2nd Edition, Oxford University Press. p. 175.</ref>
==Early life and education== Born in [[Stockholm]], Forsell was the son of Carl August Forsell, a sea captain, and Axeline Forsell (née Åberg). Before his singing career, he served in the [[Swedish Army]]; becoming a second lieutenant in 1890 and lieutenant in 1896. In 1897 he requested and was granted an honorable dismissal from the army, but continue to serve as a member of the [[Upplands regemente (infantry)|Uppland Regiment]] reserves through 1901.
While serving in the army, he pursued voice studies with [[Julius Günther]] at the [[Royal College of Music, Stockholm]] from 1892-1894. After graduating from college he studied singing further in Paris in 1895-1896 and later in Stockholm with [[Hedvig Willman]] and [[Signe Hebbe]].<ref name="oper">[http://hosting.triboni.com/triboni/exec?method=com.operissimo.artist.webDisplay&id=ffcyoieagxaaaaabatji&xsl=webDisplay&searchStr=John Forsell at operissimo.com]</ref>
==Singing career== Forsell made his operatic debut at the [[Royal Swedish Opera]], Stockholm, in 1896 as Figaro in ''[[The Barber of Seville]]''. He would remain that [[opera house]]'s premier baritone through 1918, and thereafter appeared only periodically at that theatre up until his retirement from the stage in 1938. He sang in several world premieres with the company, including [[Wilhelm Stenhammar]]'s ''Tirfing'' (1898) and [[Andreas Hallén]]'s ''[[Valdemarskatten]]'' (1899, the title role of [[Valdemar IV of Denmark]]). He also appeared in the Swedish premieres of ''[[Eugene Onegin (opera)|Eugene Onegin]]'' (1903, title role), ''[[Tosca]]'' (1904, Scarpia), and ''[[Salome (opera)|Salome]]'' (1909, Jochanaan).<ref name="oper"/>
Forsell also established an international career. From 1902-1906 he sang regularly at the [[Royal Danish Theatre]] in Copenhagen. In 1909-1910 he appeared at the [[Metropolitan Opera]] in New York City, performing such parts as Tonio in ''[[Pagliacci]]'', Amfortas in ''[[Parsifal]]'', Figaro in ''The Barber of Seville'', Telramund in ''[[Lohengrin (opera)|Lohengrin]]'', Germont in ''[[La traviata]]'' and Yeletsky in the United States premiere of [[Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky|Tchaikovsky]]'s ''[[The Queen of Spades (opera)|The Queen of Spades]]''.
The title role in [[Mozart]]'s ''[[Don Giovanni]]'' was probably his most famous interpretation. He sang the part numerous times, including during the 1909 season at the [[Royal Opera House]], [[Covent Garden]], London, and at the 1930 [[Salzburg Festival]]. Other major opera houses in which Forsell sang the Don and various leading parts were the [[Berlin State Opera]], the [[Dutch National Opera]], and the [[Vienna State Opera]]. In 1915 he portrayed the role of the Foreigner/Francesco del Giocondo in the world premiere of [[Max von Schillings]]'s ''[[Mona Lisa (opera)|Mona Lisa]]'' at the [[Staatsoper Stuttgart]].<ref name="oper"/>
== Opera director, teacher, and later life== Forsell become the Director (Intendant) of the Royal Swedish Opera at the start of the 1923-1924 season, and performed less frequently on stage as a consequence. His voice, however, remained in fine condition. His final opera performance was on his 70th birthday when he sang the role of Count Almaviva in Mozart's ''[[The Marriage of Figaro]]'' at the RSO. He retired from his director's position in May 1939 and died in Stockholm two years later. His wife, soprano Gurli Carlström (married 1901), pre-deceased him in 1935. Their son, [[Björn Forsell]], was also a successful opera singer.<ref name="oper"/>
In addition to his administrative duties at Stockholm's opera house during the 1920s and '30s, Forsell taught voice as a professor of singing at the Royal College of Music, Stockholm. His pupils included [[Joel Berglund]], [[Jussi Björling]], [[Magna Lykseth-Scherfven]], [[Aksel Schiøtz]], [[Hjördis Schymberg]], [[Set Svanholm]], and [[Inez Wassner]].<ref name="oper"/>
== Recordings== Forsell's [[phonograph|gramophone]] legacy consists of several batches of acoustic 78-rpm discs of arias and songs (made initially by the [[Gramophone & Typewriter Company]] prior to [[World War I]]) and some subsequent electrical recordings of live stage performances. Many of these recordings are available on modern CD reissues, most notably a four-disc anthology produced in 1994 by Caprice Records (CAP 21586). When discussing Forsell's impressive legacy on disc, the British audio restoration engineer Keith Hardwick has this to say: "His voice was a dark, warm, expressive baritone, very well produced and equalized."<ref>"Biographical Notes" for ''A Record of Singers Supplement 1902-1912'', OCLC 9078336, published London, 1982, by EMI Records Ltd.</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Forsell, John}} [[Category:1868 births]] [[Category:1941 deaths]] [[Category:Litteris et Artibus recipients]] [[Category:Members of the Royal Swedish Academy of Music]] [[Category:Opera managers]] [[Category:Operatic baritones]] [[Category:Royal College of Music, Stockholm alumni]] [[Category:Royal College of Music, Stockholm faculty]] [[Category:Voice teachers]] [[Category:19th-century Swedish opera singers]] [[Category:20th-century Swedish singers]]

{{for|the American librarian|John W. Berry (librarian)}} {{BLP sources|date=December 2012}} '''John W. Berry''' is a Professor Emeritus of Psychology at [[Queen's University]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.queensu.ca/psychology/People/Emeritus-Retired/JohnBerry.html |title=Department of Psychology - John Berry |publisher=Queensu.ca |date= |accessdate=2012-12-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121121005605/http://www.queensu.ca/psychology/People/Emeritus-Retired/JohnBerry.html |archivedate=2012-11-21 |df= }}</ref> He can be seen as one of the main establishers of the field of [[acculturation]] psychology. Berry has been described as a person that "has led, if not defined, contemporary approaches to acculturation."<ref>Ward, C.(2008) [https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.ijintrel.2007.11.002 Thinking outside the Berry boxes: New perspectives on identity, acculturation and intercultural relations.] "International Journal of Intercultural Relations", 32(2), 105-114.</ref>
==Life== He attended [[Sir George Williams University]] in [[Montreal]] from which he obtained a B.A. in 1963. He then undertook graduate work at the [[University of Edinburgh]] from which he obtained a PhD in 1966. He was a faculty member for most of his career at [[Queen's University]] from which he is now an emeritus professor. He has held visiting appointments at many institutions including the [[Netherlands Institute for Advanced Study]] and the National Research University Higher School of Economics, in Russia.
==Work== One of his well-known theories is the four-fold model of acculturation strategies, involving the strategies of [[Cultural assimilation|Assimilation]], [[Racial separation|Separation]], [[Racial integration|Integration]] and [[Marginalization]].
According to Google Scholar, his work has been cited over 70,000 times.<ref>{{cite web|title=Google Scholar John Berry|url=https://scholar.google.co.uk/citations?hl=en&user=1Yrc0moAAAAJ&view_op=list_works&authuser=1&sortby=pubdate|accessdate=27 October 2018}}</ref>
==Awards== * Honorary Life Fellow, [[Canadian Psychological Association]] <ref>{{cite web|title=CPA Fellows|url=https://www.cpa.ca/aboutcpa/cpaawards/fellows|accessdate=27 October 2018}}</ref> * Fellow - [[International Association for Cross-Cultural Psychology]] * Fellow - International Academy for Intercultural Research.
* 1998 - Donald O. Hebb Award for Distinguished Contributions to Psychology as a Science, Canadian Psychological Association<ref>{{cite web|title=CPA Award Descriptions and Past Recipients|url=https://www.cpa.ca/aboutcpa/cpaawards/awarddescriptions|accessdate=27 October 2018}}</ref> * 1999 - Interamerican Psychology Prize, SOCIEDAD INTERAMERICANA DE PSICOLOGÍA <ref>{{cite web|title=INTERAMERICAN PSYCHOLOGY AWARD|url=https://sipsych.org/awards/interamerican-psychology-award|accessdate=27 October 2018}}</ref> * 2001 - Doc. Hon. Causa, [[University of Athens]] * 2001 - Doc. Hon. Causa, [[University of Geneva]] * 2005 - Lifetime Contribution Award * 2012 - Award for Distinguished Contributions to the International Advancement of Psychology, Canadian Psychological Association <ref>{{cite web|title=CPA Award Descriptions and Past Recipients|url=https://www.cpa.ca/aboutcpa/cpaawards/awarddescriptions|accessdate=27 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Psychology Today Interview with Dr. J.W. Berry|url=https://www.psychologytoday.com/gb/blog/finding-new-home/201803/acculturation-and-migration-interview-dr-j-w-berry|accessdate=27 October 2018}}</ref>
==Main publications== * Berry, J.W. (1997). Immigration, acculturation, and adaptation [[Applied Psychology]], 46(1), 5-34. * Berry, J.W.(1990). Psychology of acculturation. In Berman, John J. (Ed), Nebraska Symposium on Motivation, 1989: Cross-cultural perspectives.Current theory and research in motivation, Vol. 37., (pp. 201–234). Lincoln, NE, US: University of Nebraska Press. * Berry, J.W., Kim, U., Minde, T., & Mok, D. (1987). Comparative studies of acculturative stress [[International Migration Review]], 21(3), 491-511. * Berry, J.W., Poortinga, Y.H., Segall, M.H., Dasen, P.R. (2002). Cross-Cultural Psychology: Research and Applications. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Berry, John W.}} [[Category:Psychology educators]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Cross-cultural psychology]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox artist | bgcolour = silver | name = Knox Martin | image = Knox Martin in his 50s.jpg | imagesize = 200px | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1923|2|12|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Barranquilla]], [[Colombia]] | nationality = American | field = [[Painting|Painter]], [[muralist]], [[sculptor]] | training = [[Art Students League of New York]] | movement = [[Abstract expressionism]], [[New York School (art)|New York School]] | works = ''[[Venus (mural)|Venus]]'' (1970), ''[[Woman with bicycle]]'' (1979) | awards = [[Legion of Honour|Chevalier of the Legion of Honour]], [[National Endowment for the Arts|NEA]] Grant, [[Pollock-Krasner Foundation]] Grants, [[Adolph and Esther Gottlieb Foundation]] Grant, [[Benjamin West Clinedinst]] Memorial Medal (Artists' Fellowship, Inc.), Mary & Maxwell Desser Memorial Award ([[National Academy of Design]]), J. Sanford Saltus Medal for Painting (National Academy of Design), Kept Memorial Prize (National Academy of Design), Desser Award for Painting (National Academy of Design), C.A.P.S. Grant, Longview Fellowships}} '''Knox Martin''' (born February 12, 1923) is an American [[Painting|painter]], [[sculptor]] and [[muralist]]. Born in [[Barranquilla]], [[Colombia]], he studied at the [[Art Students League of New York]] from 1946 till 1950. He is one of the leading members of the [[New York School (art)|New York School]] of artists and writers. He lives and works in New York City. ==Early life== Knox Martin is the oldest son of Lieutenant William Knox Martin, a Virginia-born early aviation pioneer and flyer, and his wife Isabel Vieco, who were married in the [[Panama Canal Zone|Canal Zone]] in [[Panama]] in 1921. Knox Martin Sr., painter, poet, early test pilot, was the first man to fly over the [[Andes]] mountains.{{cite web|url=http://www.knoxmartin.com/about-knox-martin.html |title=About Knox Martin}} Six years after his marriage, Martin Sr. was fatally injured in an automobile accident in [[Watertown, New York]].[http://earlyaviators.com/emartin.htm William Knox Martin- earlyaviators.com]
His widow Isabel relocated with her three young sons from [[Salem, Virginia]] to [[New York City]].{{cite web|url=http://www.janosgatgallery.com/JANOS_GAT_GALLERY/Knox_Martin_1.html |title=Knox Martin |publisher=Janosgatgallery.com |date=2003-09-12 |accessdate=2012-04-18}} ==Early career== After serving in the [[United States Coast Guard]][https://aintmarching.net/2009/06/08/for-d-day-anniversary-the-voice-of-one-who-knows/ For D-Day anniversary: the voice of one who knows] during World War II, Knox Martin attended the Art Students League of New York on the G.I. Bill from 1946 to 1950, where he studied with [[Harry Sternberg]],[http://www.ifpda.org/content/node/2142 Harry Sternberg-IFPDA] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130424053323/http://www.ifpda.org/content/node/2142 |date=2013-04-24 }} Vaclav Vytlacil,[https://web.archive.org/web/20160314185435/http://theartstudentsleague.org/Residency/AboutVaclavVytlacil.aspx The Art Students League: About Vaclav Vytlacil] [[Will Barnet]],[http://frenchculture.org/visual-and-performing-arts/news/france-honors-will-barnet-chevalier-order-arts-letters France Honors Will Barnet with the Order of Arts and Letters] and [[Morris Kantor]].
In 1954, Martin's friend [[Franz Kline]] placed a painting of his in the [[Stable Gallery]] Annual.{{cite web|url=http://www.worldcatlibraries.org/oclc/50666793&tab=holdings |title=''New York School Abstract Expressionists Artists Choice by Artists,'' |publisher=Worldcatlibraries.org |date= |accessdate=2012-04-18}} Charles Egan of the [[Charles Egan Gallery]] saw Martin's painting at the Stable Gallery and asked him to show his work in a one-man show for the tenth anniversary of the Egan Gallery.{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1954/09/16/archives/about-art-and-artists-knox-martin-impresses-in-first-oneman-show.html | work=The New York Times | title=About Art and Artists; Knox Martin Impresses in First One-Man Show | date=September 16, 1954 | accessdate=April 28, 2010}} ==Work== Knox Martin is best known for his repertory of [[sign (semiotics)|sign]]s and [[symbols]] that allude to nature and, in particular, to the female form. Flatly and freely painted in brilliant colors, his works have often been executed on a grand scale, as in the outdoor [[Mural|wall painting]], ''[[Woman with bicycle]]'', at West Houston and MacDougal Streets in [[Manhattan]].{{cite news| url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=950DE1DF1039F933A05755C0A967948260 | work=The New York Times | first=Vivien | last=Raynor | title=Art; Knox Martin: Angry But More Human | date=June 30, 1981}} He mostly creates painting, sculpture and wall paintings using media such as [[acrylic paint|acrylic]], [[collage]], [[fresco]], [[ink]] drawing (pen and ink), mixed media/multimedia, and [[oil]].{{cite web|url=http://www.askart.com/AskART/artists/search/ArtistKeywords.aspx?artist=32742 |title=Knox Martin - Artist, Art - Knox Martin |publisher=Askart.com |date= |accessdate=2012-04-18}} [[File:Venus Mural.JPG|thumb|''Venus'' mural]] One of his wall paintings in New York City is the twelve-story mural ''[[Venus (mural)|Venus]]''.{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/02/11/nyregion/thecity/11venu.html?ex=1328850000&en=8f4515c95db4a18e&ei=5124&partner=permalink&exprod=permalink | work=The New York Times | first=Alex | last=Mindlin | title=After a 37-Year Run, a Roadside Venus to Be Veiled | date=February 11, 2007}} Painted in 1970, it is located on the south side of [[Bayview Correctional Facility]] at 19th Street and the West Side Highway.{{cite web|url=http://www.newyorkartworld.com/commentary/KnoxMartin-RoadsideVenus.html |title=Knox Martin and his Roadside Venus |publisher=Newyorkartworld.com |date=2007-02-11 |accessdate=2012-04-18 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070822211418/http://www.newyorkartworld.com/commentary/KnoxMartin-RoadsideVenus.html |archivedate=August 22, 2007 }}
"Traditionally the goddess of love and fertility, Venus represents woman, erotic and supple, but it also conveys Knox Martin's love affair with New York. Venus is his love poem to the city where he has always lived, a place that is part of his being. The feminine, curvilinear shapes of the image are in direct contrast with the straight forms that intersect the composition. The overwhelming size of this enormous mural only intensifies the experience of female shapes, the linear aspects of the painted composition, and of the surrounding architecture. In an era when art was reaching out to the masses with pop culture, this huge mural was Knox Martin's way of touching a public that would never venture into an art gallery." Marilyn Kushner, Knox Martin: Early Work, exh. cat. (New York: Janos Gat Gallery, 1997)
==Collections== Knox Martin's work is included in the collections of [[Whitney Museum of American Art]],[http://collection.whitney.org/object/366 Whitney Museum of American Art Collection] [[Museum of Modern Art]],{{cite web|url=http://www.moma.org/collection/artist.php?artist_id=28705 |title=Museum of Modern Art Collection |publisher=Moma.org |date= |accessdate=2012-04-18}} [[Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden]],[https://hirshhorn.si.edu/search-results/search-result-details/?edan_search_value=hmsg_86.2463 Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden] [[Art Students League of New York]], [[Brooklyn Museum of Art]], [[National Academy of Design]], [[National Arts Club]], [[New York University]], [[Addison Gallery of American Art]], [[Albright-Knox Art Gallery]], [[Art Institute of Chicago]], [[Art Museum of Southeast Texas]], [[Baltimore Museum of Art]], [[Berkeley Art Museum]], [[Blanton Museum of Art]], [[Boca Raton Museum of Art]], [[Chrysler Museum of Art]], [[Corcoran Gallery of Art]], [[Dallas Museum of Art]], [[Denver Art Museum]], Hand Art Center, [[Herbert F. Johnson Museum of Art]], [[Heckscher Museum of Art]], [[Hofstra University Museum]], [[Indianapolis Museum of Art]],{{cite web|url=http://collection.imamuseum.org/results.html?name=Martin,%20Knox |title=Indianapolis Museum of Art Collection |publisher=Imamuseum.org |date= |accessdate=2012-04-18}} Ithaca Museum, [[Lowe Art Museum]], [[Montclair Art Museum]], [[Minneapolis Institute of Arts]],{{cite web | url=https://collections.artsmia.org/index.php?page=detail&id=56582 | title= Minneapolis Institute of Arts | accessdate=2014-04-24 | publisher=artsmia.org}} [[Newark Museum]], [[Oklahoma City Museum of Art]], [[Portland Art Museum]], [[Provincetown Art Association and Museum]],https://www.paam.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/10/PAAM_collection_web_version.pdf [[Reading Public Museum]], [[Southern Alleghenies Museum of Art]], Springfield Art Museum, [[The Museum of Fine Arts, Houston]],{{cite web | url=https://www.mfah.org/art/detail/60352?returnUrl=%2Fart%2Fsearch%3Fq%3D%2522Knox%2BMartin%2522 |title=The Museum of Fine Arts, Houston Collection}} [[Toledo Museum of Art]], [[University of Kentucky Art Museum]],http://finearts.uky.edu/art-museum/exhibitions/one-one [[Weatherspoon Art Museum]],{{cite web|url=http://weatherspoon.uncg.edu/collections/results/?search_type=advanced_search&artist=Martin%2C+Knox&title=&start_year=&end_year=&object_type=none&medium=&x=0&y=0 |title=Weatherspoon Art Museum Collection |publisher=Weatherspoon.uncg.edu |date= |accessdate=2012-04-18}} [[Wellesley College]], [[William Benton Museum of Art]], [[Israel Museum]], Ludwig Museum in Budapest,https://www.ludwigmuseum.hu/en/author/martin-knox and the [[Bibliothèque Nationale]]. In 2002 Martin was named to the [[National Academy of Design]].{{cite web|url=https://www.nationalacademy.org/search?q=Knox%20Martin |title=National Academy Museum and School of Fine Arts |publisher=Nationalacademy.org |date= |accessdate=2012-04-18}} In the fall of 2010 (September 15-November 13) Martin had a one-man show of his Black and White Paintings at [[Woodward Gallery]] in New York City.{{cite web|url=http://woodwardgallery.net/exhibitions/woman-black-and-white-paintings/|title=Knox Martin- Woman: Black and White Paintings |publisher=Woodwardgallery.net |date=2010-11-13 |accessdate=2012-04-18}}{{cite web|author=Robert Shuster |url=http://www.villagevoice.com/2010-10-20/art/knox-martin-at-woodward-gallery-robert-wilson-at-paula-cooper-charlotte-schulz-at-smack-mellon/ |title=Knox Martin at Woodward Gallery, Best in Show by Robert Shuster, Village Voice, October 20, 2010 |publisher=Villagevoice.com |date=2010-10-20 |accessdate=2012-04-18}}{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?time_continue=1&v=k5AtOlxwPY0|title=YouTube Video: Knox Martin Women Black and White at WOODWARD GALLERY by James Kalm}} October 6, 2012 to April 6, 2013, Martin had a solo exhibition of recent paintings, SHE,[http://www.justpaint.org/knox-martin-at-the-sam-adele-golden-gallery/ Just Paint article: Knox Martin at the Sam & Adele Golden Gallery] at the Sam & Adele Golden Gallery at [[Golden Artist Colors]] in New Berlin, New York.[http://www.thesagg.org/news.php SAGG Press Release-Knox Martin] September 13, 2013 to October 26, 2013: Knox Martin Exhibition SHE at LGTripp Gallery in Philadelphia[http://www.lgtrippgallery.com/2013/09/knox-martin-exhibition/ Knox Martin Exhibition SHE at LGTripp Gallery] On November 14, 2016, France conferred the insignia of the [[Legion of Honour]] on Martin for his contribution to the liberation of France during World War II.[https://vimeo.com/191862925 2016 Veterans Day Ceremony] ==Teaching== Knox Martin gives master classes at the [[Art Students League of New York]]. He taught at Yale Graduate School of Art, first as visiting critic in art, invited by [[Jack Tworkov]], and then as [[Professor]] of Art. He has also taught at [[New York University]], the [[University of Minnesota]], and the International School of Painting, Drawing and Sculpture in Umbria, Italy.{{cite web|url=http://www.askart.com/AskART/M/knox_martin/knox_martin.aspx |title=Knox Martin - Artist, Art - Knox Martin |publisher=Askart.com |date=1993-02-26 |accessdate=2012-04-18}} ==References== {{reflist}} == Books == * Marika Herskovic, [http://www.worldcatlibraries.org/oclc/50666793&tab=holdings New York School Abstract Expressionists Artists Choice by Artists,] (New York School Press, 2000.) {{ISBN|0-9677994-0-6}} * [[Irving Sandler]], [http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/69650842 From Avant-Garde to Pluralism: An On-The-Spot History,] (Hard Press Editions, 2006.) {{ISBN|1889097683}} ==External links== *[http://www.knoxmartin.com Knox Martin website] *[http://www.artnet.com/artists/knox-martin/biography/ Knox Martin - Artnet] *[http://www.aaa.si.edu/collections/interviews/oral-history-interview-knox-martin-16190 Knox Martin Oral History Interview, Smithsonian Archives of American Art] *[http://www.publicartfund.org/view/exhibitions/5967_venus Public Art Fund: Venus] *[http://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/fiscal/profile?id=4791 Knox Martin - The Whaling Wall] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Martin, Knox}} [[Category:Abstract expressionist artists]] [[Category:20th-century American painters]] [[Category:American male painters]] [[Category:21st-century American painters]] [[Category:American muralists]] [[Category:Painters from New York (state)]] [[Category:Art Students League of New York alumni]] [[Category:Art Students League of New York faculty]] [[Category:American educators]] [[Category:Art educators]] [[Category:1923 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:20th-century American sculptors]] [[Category:American male sculptors]] [[Category:People from Salem, Virginia]] [[Category:Sculptors from New York (state)]]

{{Orphan|date=January 2013}}
'''Leadership & Management wales''' is an organisation funded by the [[Welsh Government]] and the [[European Social Fund]] to encourage the development of leadership and management skills among businesses in [[Wales]].
It was formed in 2009<ref> {{cite web |title=Two Years in Review 2009-2011, Leadership & Management Wales, 2011 |url=http://lmw.org.uk/files/pages/2YearReportEnglish.pdf }}</ref> in response to a report entitled ''Skills That Work for Wales'',<ref> {{cite web |title=Skills That Work For Wales, Welsh Assembly Government, 2008 |url=http://wales.gov.uk/topics/educationandskills/publications/guidance/skillsthatforwales/?lang=en }}</ref> and is run by a consortium, led by [[Cardiff Business School]] at [[Cardiff University]], and also including [[Glyndwr University]], [[Aberystwyth University]], and Tattum Guest Associates. Its main office is in [[Cardiff]], with others in [[Wrexham]] and [[Aberystwyth]].
LMW states on its website that it was “formed to support businesses in developing their leadership and management development (LMD) skills, enabling them to increase efficiency and help grow the economy in Wales”.
It is part of the Welsh Government’s Workforce Development Programme and Enhancing Leadership and Management Skills (ELMS) programme. LMW runs events, conducts and commissions research, and provides online resources and information on funding and training courses.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{official website|http://www.lmw.org.uk}} *[https://ultimatelifemagazine.com/2017/12/14/maintaining-work-life-balance-2/ Maintaining Work Life Balance]

revision.text:
{{No footnotes|date=November 2010}}
The '''Lest We Forget Project''' is a project by Canadian Schools in cooperation with [[Library and Archives Canada]] and the [[Canadian War Museum]]. In this project, students attend Library & Archives to study files of [[World War I]] and [[World War II]] soldiers. This helps students understand the contributions made for them, by the military.
The program began in 2001 after Blake Seward, a history teacher from [[Smiths Falls]], [[Ontario]] decided to teach his class about World War I through researching soldiers, nurses and other participants in the war.
In January 2010, Library and Archives Canada announced cutbacks to the program. Through a joint effort with the [[Royal Canadian Legion]] and the War Museum, the program still exists for the use of students. Much of the information was made available online for the ease of research for students.
==Sources==
# [https://web.archive.org/web/20101112093805/http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/education/cenotaph/025009-1101-e.html "How The Project Came About" - Collections Canada] #[http://www.ottawasun.com/news/columnists/earl_mcrae/2010/01/19/12533356.html Lest We Forget Project - Ottawa Sun] #[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/first-world-war-workshops-soon-to-be-history/article1480416/ First World War Shops Soon To Be History - Globe & Mail] #[http://www.ucdsb.on.ca/News/Current+News/Spotlight/Seward+Award.htm "Award given to Black Seward"]
[[Category:Education in Canada]]

page.title: List of academic databases and search engines

revision.text:
This page contains a representative list of major databases and search engines useful in an academic setting for finding and accessing articles in [[academic journal]]s, [[institutional repository|institutional repositories]], archives, or other collections of [[scientific journal|scientific]] and [[academic journal|other]] articles. As the distinction between a [[database]] and a [[search engine]] is unclear for these complex [[document retrieval system]]s, see:
* the general [[list of search engines]] for all-purpose search engines that can be used for academic purposes * the article about [[bibliographic database]]s for information about databases giving bibliographic information about finding books and journal articles.
Note that "free" or "subscription" can refer both to the availability of the database or of the journal articles included. This has been indicated as precisely as possible in the lists below.

While it is a subscription product, authors can review and update their profiles via ORCID.org or by first searching for their profile at the free Scopus author lookup page. |{{no|Subscription}} |[[Elsevier]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://info.scopus.com/ |title=Scopus |publisher=Info.scopus.com |date=2013-11-21 |accessdate=2014-08-05}}</ref> |- |[[SearchTeam]] |Multidisciplinary |Students search together collaboratively for scholarly articles and resources |{{yes|Free}} |Zakta<ref>{{cite web| last = PRWeb.com| title = SNew Social Search Engine Lets People Search the Web Together With Friends| url = http://www.prweb.com/releases/SearchTeam/CollaborativeSearch/prweb8594099.htm/| accessdate = 11 August 2011 }}</ref> |- |[[Semantic Scholar]] | Multidisciplinary |It is designed to quickly highlight the most important papers and identify the connections between them.
